questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with two days of fever, vomiting, and right flank pain. The pain is intermittent and has not responded to acetaminophen or ibuprofen. The patient also had burning urination that started around the same time, which he attributed to a new body soap. Temperature is 38.5 ºC (101.3 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 145/88 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has no periumbilical or suprapubic tenderness to palpation. The serum leukocyte count is 19,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase, moderate pyuria, and the presence of white blood cell casts. Which of the following physical exam maneuvers will most likely elicit pain in this patient?

choices.text: Palpation and percussion between the right 12th rib and spine
Palpation in the left lower quadrant and waiting for report of pain in the right lower quadrant
Flexion and internal rotation of the right hip while the patient is supine
Passive extension of the right hip while the patient lies on their left side
Elevation of the patient’s right foot and striking the right heel while the patient is supine

questions.solution:
This patient with fever, flank pain, dysuria, leukocytosis, and urinalysis positive for pyuria and white blood cell casts most likely has acute pyelonephritis. Pyelonephritis is a urinary tract infection involving the kidney. Laboratory evaluation of such a patient shows leukocytosis. When kidney function is deranged, creatinine may be elevated. Urinalysis reveals bacteriuria and pyuria and may show hematuria or white blood cell casts. Urine and blood cultures should be obtained.

Patients generally present with fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and flank pain. Some patients may have difficulty describing the pain and may describe it as back or abdominal pain. Some patients have dysuria or urinary urgency/frequency during or before the onset of flank pain. Tenderness to palpation or percussion at the costovertebral angle (CVA), which is the area between the 12th rib and the spine,, is highly suggestive of acute pyelonephritis in the right clinical scenario. This patient will likely have significant CVA tenderness to palpation and percussion.  

Option Analysis

✅ Palpation and percussion between the right 12th rib and spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palpation in the left lower quadrant and waiting for report of pain in the right lower quadrant:
Incorrect: This is referred to as the Rovsing sign and, if positive, it suggests acute appendicitis. It is not associated with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Flexion and internal rotation of the right hip while the patient is supine:
Incorrect: If this maneuver causes pain, it is considered a positive obturator sign and suggests acute appendicitis. It is not associated with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Passive extension of the right hip while the patient lies on their left side:
Incorrect: If this elicits pain then it is considered a positive psoas sign and suggests acute appendicitis. It is not associated with pyelonephritis.  
❌ Elevation of the patient’s right foot and striking the right heel while the patient is supine:
Incorrect: This is the heel tap/strike sign, if it elicits pain it suggests acute peritonitis (possibly localized from acute appendicitis), not pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is hospitalized for fever, nausea, vomiting, right flank pain, and dysuria. After an initial evaluation, acute pyelonephritis is diagnosed, and the patient is started on intravenous ceftriaxone. The initial serum leukocyte count is 23,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Urine culture grows >100,000 colony-forming units of E. coli, which are susceptible to ceftriaxone. On hospital day three, the patient develops a fever after being afebrile for 24 hours. Flank pain is still present. Current temperature is 38.5 ºC (101.3 ºF), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 138/81 mmHg. Serum leukocyte count is 21,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Significant tenderness to palpation is still present at the right costovertebral angle. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient with acute pyelonephritis is not improving on appropriate antibiotics. Lack of improvement within 48 to 72 hours of initiation of treatment suggests that the antibiotic choice is incorrect (empiric antibiotic does not cover the pathogen that grows out or there is bacterial resistance to an appropriate antibiotic) or that the source of the infection must be controlled (calculus or obstruction, renal or perinephric abscess that needs intervention). This patient’s infection is sensitive to the antibiotic being used. The issue is likely a lack of source control, which raises concern for complicated pyelonephritis (e.g., abscess) requiring further imaging and possible intervention. CT of the abdomen and pelvis is generally used to diagnose physiologic or anatomical features leading to complicated pyelonephritis. If CT is not available or the patient cannot undergo radiation (e.g. a pregnant woman), ultrasound can often be used.
 

Patients with mild to moderate acute uncomplicated pyelonephritis can be treated as outpatients if they can tolerate oral antibiotics (e.g. ciprofloxacin) and oral hydration. If the patient has medical comorbidities (especially diabetes) or is very ill with persistently high fevers, severe pain, or the inability to take medications or hydrate orally, they require hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone, piperacillin-tazobactam).

Complicated pyelonephritis is associated with urolithiasis (kidney or ureteral stone), anatomic or functional urinary tract abnormalities, renal or perinephric (perirenal) abscess, recent urological manipulations, underlying immunosuppression,  and male sex. These patients need hospitalization, IV antibiotics, and a urology consultation for possible cystoscopy and intervention.

If patients on outpatient treatment are not improving, they should be admitted and started on intravenous antibiotics and hydration. Hospitalized patients, like the patient in this case, should have abdominal imaging if they are not improving despite 48 to 72 hours of appropriate antimicrobial therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Change ceftriaxone to cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient’s urine culture grew bacteria susceptible to ceftriaxone. Cefepime can be used if infection with Pseudomonas spp. is suspected or if cultures show resistance to ceftriaxone, neither of which apply in this patient’s case.  
❌ Obtain abdominal MRI:
Incorrect: While abdominal MRI can show complications of pyelonephritis, CT imaging or ultrasound would be more appropriate choices due to availability and cost-effectiveness.  
❌ Obtain a repeat urine culture:
Incorrect: The patient is unlikely to have developed a new separate urinary tract infection with a different organism, making repeat urine culture necessary. If there is a concern for inadequate source control, the next step is to pursue abdominal imaging.  
❌ Obtain a serum lactate level:
Incorrect: Lactic acid (lactate) levels help evaluate patients with sepsis since elevated levels generally suggest more severe disease. High levels can be trended to assess response to treatment, but a one-time lactate level now will have little clinical utility, and this patient is not currently exhibiting signs of sepsis.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department from a nursing home for evaluation of fever and dysuria for two days. She has become progressively more confused. The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Temperature is 102.6℉ (39.2°C), pulse is 115/min, blood pressure is 104/86 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is minimally interactive on examination. Physical examination reveals a normal cardiopulmonary exam and mild suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Results of the urinalysis are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?  

 Urinalysis 
 Color  Yellow, hazy 
 pH  6.8 
 Ketones  Negative 
 Glucose  Negative 
 Bilirubin  Negative 
 Leukocyte esterase  Positive 
 Nitrites  Positive 
 Urine Microscopy 
 RBCs  2-3/HPF 
 WBCs  >50/HPF 
 Epithelial cells  1-2/HPF 
 Bacteria  Many 
 Casts  None

choices.text: Discharge to the nursing home on oral antibiotics
Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Start intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
Place a foley catheter and admit to the general medicine floor

questions.solution:
Dysuria refers to the sensation of painful or uncomfortable urination. Patients typically describe their discomfort as a burning, tingling, or stinging sensation that occurs when urine passes through an inflamed or irritated urethra. Bladder spasms can worsen this pain.    

The causes of dysuria are categorized into infectious and non-infectious etiologies. Patients should be assessed for genital tract infections like cervicitis, epididymitis, and urethritis if they are sexually active. Patients should be evaluated for lower urinary tract infections (UTIs) and pyelonephritis. If there is no evidence for infection, then they should be evaluated for non-infectious causes of dysuria like benign prostatic hypertrophy, nephrolithiasis, urologic malignancy, and interstitial cystitis.    

Patients presenting to the emergency department with complaints of dysuria require assessment of the ABCDEs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure) to determine if they are stable or unstable. This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of sepsis from an underlying UTI, with urinalysis and urine microscopy showing evidence of a UTI, likely secondary to E. coli (positive nitrites). The patient requires stabilization with intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.   

Option Analysis

❌ Discharge to the nursing home on oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of sepsis and hemodynamic instability, and urinalysis and urine microscopy indicate a urinary tract infection. This patient requires admission, IV antibiotics, and stabilization.   
❌ Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: Imaging can detect intra-abdominal sources of infection; however, this patient is hemodynamically unstable and requires immediate stabilization. Further imaging can be obtained once the patient is stabilized if clinically indicated.  
✅ Start intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Place a foley catheter and admit to the general medicine floor:
Incorrect: Obstruction of urinary outflow can result in urinary tract infections. Catheter placement to relieve obstruction may be needed in some patients. This patient is hemodynamically unstable and requires immediate measures for stabilization including antibiotics and IV fluids.   
❌ Administer vasopressors:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting as hemodynamically unstable with signs of sepsis. Fluids should be administered prior to initiation of vasopressors.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of mild lower abdominal discomfort, increased urinary frequency, and burning with urination for the past two days. The patient was discharged from the hospital one week ago following an abdominal hysterectomy for abnormal vaginal bleeding. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urine culture and sensitivities are shown below. The medication indicated in the treatment of this patient’s urinary symptoms inhibits which of the following bacterial cell processes? 

 Microorganism     >100,000 CFU Klebsiella pneumoniae    
 Antibiotic     Sensitivity (R=resistant; S=sensitive)    
 Penicillin     R    
 Nitrofurantoin     R    
 Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole     R    
 Gentamicin     S    
 Meropenem     R    
 Aztreonam     R
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from acute cystitis, secondary to infection with Klebsiella pneumoniae. This organism is resistant to multiple medications except for gentamicin, an aminoglycoside.

Aminoglycosides (gentamicin, tigecycline, neomycin, amikacin, and tobramycin) are bactericidal antimicrobials that irreversibly inhibit the ribosomal initiation complex through binding of the 30S subunit and resultant misreading of bacterial mRNA. Ultimately, this results in the incorporation of incorrect peptides, and nonfunctional bacterial proteins. Additionally, aminoglycosides bound to the 30s subunit prevent translocation (the final step in protein synthesis). Aminoglycosides require an O2-dependent cotransporter on the cell membrane and are, therefore ineffective against anaerobes. These antibiotics are primarily effective against gram-negative aerobic rods.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Peptidoglycan cross-linking :
Incorrect: Peptidoglycan cross-linking is inhibited by penicillin, cephalosporins, carbapenems and monobactams. Klebsiella pneumoniae is resistant to all of these medications. 
❌ Folic acid synthesis :
Incorrect: A combination of trimethoprim and sulfonamide (sulfamethoxazole) serves as one of the most common medications used to treat urinary tract infections. This patient’s urine culture demonstrates resistance to this medication. 
✅ Protein synthesis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ mRNA synthesis :
Incorrect: Rifampin inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, which is responsible for mRNA synthesis. It serves as one of the main components of the anti-tuberculosis treatment regime. This medication, however, is not indicated in the treatment of lower urinary tract infections. 
❌ Peptidoglycan synthesis :
Incorrect: Vancomycin inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. It is primarily effective against gram positive organisms.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for partial colectomy for resection of localized colorectal cancer. The surgery is completed without complications. In the postoperative period, the patient develops urinary retention, and a urinary catheter is inserted. CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows no surgical complications. Three days later, the patient develops a fever, chills, mild suprapubic pain, and a burning sensation during urinating. The patient has no diarrhea, cough, or shortness of breath. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), blood pressure is 132/77 mmHg, and pulse is 96/min. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no evidence of purulent drainage or erythema around the surgical site. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the suprapubic region. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, chills, suprapubic pain, and dysuria associated with postoperative urinary retention and urinary catheter placement. In combination, these findings are most concerning for a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI). Symptomatic patients can present with fever, suprapubic discomfort, dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. Common physical examination findings include suprapubic tenderness and costovertebral angle tenderness (if there is pyelonephritis). In severe cases, especially in older patients, altered mental status such as confusion or lethargy may be seen. Laboratory testing will show leukocytosis, pyuria, and bacteriuria.

CAUTIs are urinary tract infections in the presence of an indwelling urinary catheter or after the recent removal (within 48 hours) of a catheter. To decrease the risk of patients developing CAUTIs, urinary catheters should be avoided if possible and removed as soon as they are no longer needed.

Symptomatic UTIs are the most commonly diagnosed and necessitate antibiotics. Asymptomatic bacteriuria and asymptomatic UTIs are discovered incidentally on urinalysis and urine culture as the patient will not have any symptoms. If urine and blood cultures grow the same urinary pathogen, the patient has an asymptomatic CAUTI and should receive antibiotics. If an asymptomatic patient has a positive urine culture and negative blood culture, the patient has asymptomatic bacteriuria. Antibiotics should only be given for asymptomatic bacteriuria in patients with risk factors (e.g., pregnancy, recent urologic procedure).  

Option Analysis

❌ Hospital-acquired pneumonia:
Incorrect: This patient, with fever, chills, and mild suprapubic pain after surgery, has no respiratory symptoms and normal findings on auscultation. Pneumonia is very unlikely. Since a urinary catheter has been in place for several days to help manage urinary retention, this patient is more likely to have a catheter-associated urinary tract infection.  
✅ Catheter-associated urinary tract infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intra-abdominal abscess:
Incorrect: An intra-abdominal abscess can present with fever and chills. However, this patient’s pain is primarily localized to the suprapubic region and is associated with dysuria (pain with urination). In combination, these findings are more concerning for a catheter-associated urinary tract infection.  
❌ Bowel perforation with pneumoperitoneum:
Incorrect: Bowel perforation with pneumoperitoneum is a severe compilation of intra-abdominal surgery, typically causing severe abdominal pain, distention, fever, and chills. This patient’s abdominal pain is localized to the suprapubic area and is mild. The normal blood pressure and heart rate with mild abdominal pain make perforation very unlikely.  
❌ Clostridioides difficile diarrhea:
Incorrect: Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium difficile) is a Gram-positive bacterium that can lead to diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. Risk factors include recent antibiotic use and hospitalization. This patient has no diarrhea, and a catheter-associated urinary tract infection better explains the symptoms. Risk factors include recent antibiotic use and hospitalization.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with an episode of acute decompensated heart failure. He is admitted to the ICU for management and monitoring. An indwelling urinary catheter is placed for urine output monitoring. On day 5 of hospitalization, the nurse reports that his urine appears cloudy with normal urine output. The patient reports chills and lower abdominal pain. He does not complain of low back pain. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0 F), blood pressure is 92/64 mm Hg, pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on 5L nasal cannula. Physical examination is significant for suprapubic tenderness. There is no costophrenic angle tenderness. Laboratory results are significant for leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. Urinalysis shows pyuria and is positive for nitrites and leukocyte esterase. IV fluids are initiated. Urine and blood cultures are obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Remove the urinary catheter and administer IV cefepime
Remove the urinary catheter and administer oral ciprofloxacin
Leave the urinary catheter in place and administer IV amoxicillin/clavulanate
Remove the urinary catheter and administer IV fluconazole

questions.solution:
This patient, with a 5-day history of an indwelling urinary catheter, develops fever, suprapubic tenderness, and urinalysis findings that are consistent with a catheter-associated urinary tract infection. The presence of systemic findings of infection (chills, fever, hypotension, and tachycardia), along with the presence of leukocytosis, and an elevated CRP on laboratory evaluation further support the diagnosis of a complicated lower UTI and possible urosepsis.

Catheter-associated urinary tract infections (CAUTI) are common healthcare-associated infections, often leading to increased morbidity, prolonged hospitalization, and higher healthcare costs. They occur in patients who are currently catheterized or have been catheterized within the past 48 hours. The presence of a urinary catheter provides a direct route for nosocomial bacteria to enter the urinary tract and increases the risk of infection. Timely management of CAUTIs includes removal of the indwelling urinary catheter and initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy. Cefepime, a fourth-generation cephalosporin, offers broad-spectrum coverage against both gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is more prevalent in CAUTIs. Alternative antibiotic options depend on the severity of the infection, the suspected presence of multi-drug resistant organisms, and local resistance patterns. Empiric antibiotic therapy should be initiated promptly and adjusted later based on culture and sensitivity results.

In addition to supportive care and empiric antibiotics, it is crucial to address the source of infection by removing the indwelling urinary catheter. If a new catheter is necessary for ongoing monitoring or management, a new one can be inserted.  

Option Analysis

✅ Remove the urinary catheter and administer IV cefepime:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Remove the urinary catheter and administer oral ciprofloxacin:
Incorrect: While removing the catheter is indicated in a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI), oral ciprofloxacin is not the optimal choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient. IV antibiotics are preferred to ensure adequate drug delivery and rapid therapeutic effect.  
❌ Leave the urinary catheter in place and administer IV amoxicillin/clavulanate:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are indicated, the urinary catheter should also be removed to eliminate the source of infection and prevent further complications.  
❌ Remove the urinary catheter and administer IV fluconazole:
Incorrect: Although removing the urinary catheter is indicated, IV fluconazole is not the drug of choice for managing a patient with suspected bacterial UTI. Fluconazole is an antifungal agent that can be added to the treatment if there is evidence of fungal growth on cultures.  
❌ Order a renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: An abdominal CT scan, not a renal ultrasound, is indicated when there is suspicion of renal abscess formation, or urinary tract obstruction in addition to a suspected UTI. This patient with an acute presentation is not consistent with renal abscess or obstruction. Initial management should focus on eliminating the source of infection by removing the urinary catheter and treating with antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of burning with urination for the past three days. Yesterday, the patient also developed right-sided flank pain and chills. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 38.2 ºC (100.8 ºF), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 95/50 mmHg, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation at the right costovertebral angle. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. Pregnancy test is negative. The serum leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3, and serum creatinine is 0.8 mg/dL. Urinalysis, urine culture, and blood cultures are obtained. Urinalysis is shown below. IV fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
 
Urinalysis Test  
Result
pH
5.0
Leukocyte esterase
Positive
Nitrites
Positive
Bacteria
Moderate
WBC
20-30/hpf  
RBC
0-1/hpf
Squamous epithelial cells
0-1/hpf
questions.solution:
Acute pyelonephritis is a urinary tract infection involving the kidneys, as opposed to cystitis which involves the bladder. Patients generally present with fever, chills, and flank pain and have CVA tenderness on palpation. Laboratory evaluation will likely show leukocytosis. If kidney function is deranged, then creatinine may be elevated. Urinalysis will show bacteriuria and pyuria and may show hematuria or white blood cell casts. Nitrites may be seen if E. coli is the causative pathogen. Urine and blood cultures should be obtained. This patient with acute pyelonephritis is unstable with urosepsis, and should be admitted to the hospital for IV fluids, IV ceftriaxone, and further workup.

Pyelonephritis can be classified as uncomplicated or complicated. Complicated pyelonephritis is diagnosed when certain host factors exist like immunosuppression or the presence of comorbidities like diabetes mellitus or when structural factors exist like obstruction from nephrolithiasis or renal abscess. Uncomplicated pyelonephritis in a stable patient can be treated as an outpatient if the patient can tolerate oral antibiotics (e.g. ciprofloxacin) and oral hydration and has no significant medical comorbidities. If the patient has medical comorbidities, is very ill, or cannot tolerate oral medication or hydration, they require hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone, piperacillin-tazobactam).

Complicated pyelonephritis is associated with urinary system pathologies such as urolithiasis (kidney or ureteral stones), renal abscess, or perinephric (perirenal) abscess and also with host factors like male sex and immunosuppression. These patients need hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics, a urology consult, and possibly an interventional radiology consult. Pyelonephritis in pregnant patients is also treated with hospitalization and IV antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

✅ Start intravenous ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start oral nitrofurantoin:
Incorrect: This patient likely has pyelonephritis and sepsis, given the flank pain and CVA tenderness on exam. While nitrofurantoin is an appropriate antibiotic choice in cystitis, it does not concentrate well in renal parenchyma and tubules and is ineffective for treating pyelonephritis.  
❌ Perform cystoscopy:
Incorrect: Cystoscopy could be appropriate if this patient had findings consistent with obstruction or complicated pyelonephritis secondary to urolithiasis. This patient has 0-1 RBCs in the urine (making stones unlikely) and no imaging has been done yet to suggest urolithiasis.  
❌ Repeat urinalysis:
Incorrect: A urinalysis with many squamous epithelial cells is difficult to interpret as it represents a poor specimen collection due to contamination from the external genitalia. Urinalysis with epithelial contamination should be repeated, but this patient’s urinalysis has no evidence of contamination.  
❌ Start norepinephrine infusion:
Incorrect: While this patient’s blood pressure is low, she has just received intravenous fluids. She should continue to receive fluids and be started on empiric antibiotics; if she remains hypotensive, then vasopressors can be started.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with a 4-day history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency and urgency, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. She does not have fevers, flank pain, vaginal discharge, and itching. She is not sexually active. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, she has suprapubic tenderness, without rebound or guarding. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals leukocytes and leukocyte esterase, but no nitrites or blood. A clean-catch urine sample is sent for culture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has cystitis. Cystitis is a urinary tract infection (UTI) of the bladder/lower urinary tract and is most commonly caused by bacterial infections. Typical symptoms of cystitis include dysuria (painful urination), increased frequency of urination, urgency, a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying, and occasionally hematuria. The onset of symptoms tends to be acute, developing over a short period, which aligns with this patient's 4-day history of symptoms. Physical examination may revealsuprapubic tenderness.  

The urinalysis findings further support the diagnosis of cystitis. The presence of pyuria or leukocytes seen on urine microscopy indicates an inflammatory or infectious process within the urinary tract. White blood cell count ≥10 leukocytes/microL is consistent with a urinary tract infection. The presence of nitrites, produced by certain bacteria like E. coli, are often detected in bacterial UTIs, but their absence does not rule out a UTI, especially in the context of symptoms suggestive of cystitis. The presence of leukocyte esterase indicates a urinary tract infection since it is an enzyme released by leukocytes. A urine culture showing bacteriuria (≥105 colony-forming units/mL of a uropathogen) confirms the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vaginal candidiasis:
Incorrect: Vaginal candidiasis, or yeast infection, is often caused by antibiotic use, which disrupts the normal vaginal flora and allows for Candida overgrowth. Symptoms include itching and burning of the vagina, and a characteristic thick, white "cottage cheese-like" vaginal discharge.   
❌ Gonococcal cervicitis and urethritis:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. Cervicitis and urethritis in women are commonly caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. With cervicitis, there is typically a mucopurulent discharge. Urethritis may also be seen concurrently and cause dysuria, however, most women with Neisseria gonorrhoeae are asymptomatic. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who is not sexually active.  
❌ Interstitial cystitis:
Incorrect: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition characterized by bladder pain, urgency, frequency, and nocturia. Onset of symptoms in interstitial cystitis tends to be more insidious and chronic, rather than acute, as seen with this patient. The urine is sterile in interstitial cystitis.  
❌ Chlamydial cervicitis and urethritis:
Incorrect: Chlamydia trachomatis is a sexually transmitted bacteria that can cause urethritis, leading to symptoms of dysuria. In women, chlamydial infection can also ascend to involve the cervix, producing a mucopurulent cervical discharge. While this patient does have dysuria, she has no vaginal discharge and is not sexually active.   
✅ Cystitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of increased urinary frequency and burning with urination for the past 2 days. She has mild lower abdominal discomfort but no abnormal vaginal discharge. The patient has a history of 2 similar episodes in the past which was treated adequately with antibiotics. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.6 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild lower abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urine is sent for culture and sensitivity, and the patient is started on empiric treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. The patient returned 4 days later with little improvement in her symptoms. Urine culture sensitivities are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for the treatment failure in this patient?  

 Microorganism  Escherichia coli 
 Drug  Sensitivity (R = resistant, S = susceptible) 
 Penicillin  S 
 Nitrofurantoin  R 
 Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole  R 
 Gentamicin  S 
 Meropenem  S 
 Ciprofloxacin  S

choices.text: Poor interaction with penicillin binding proteins
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase

questions.solution:
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) combinations act synergistically by blocking folic acid synthesis in two sequential steps and was prescribed to this patient for the treatment of uncomplicated urinary tract infection. As seen in urine culture, E. coli in this patient is resistant to TMP-SMX. Bacterial resistance to sulfonamides is common and may be plasmid-mediated. Sulfamethoxazole (a sulfonamide) is a structural analog of p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and competes with it for the active site of the enzyme dihydropteroate synthetase (DHPS) in the first step of folate synthesis. This competitive inhibition can be overcome by an excess of PABA. Other mechanisms of resistance include decreased intracellular accumulation of the drugs (by decreased uptake), or a decrease in the sensitivity of dihydropteroate synthase to the sulfonamide by alteration in its structure.  

Option Analysis

✅ Increased synthesis of p-Aminobenzoic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Poor interaction with penicillin binding proteins:
Incorrect: Resistance to penicillins is caused by changes in the PBPs in the bacterial cell membrane, which decreases the penicillin-binding and reduces the ability of the antibiotic to kill the targeted bacteria. This patient is receiving treatment with TMP-SMX.  
❌ Mutated DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolones is due primarily to chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase. This patient’s bacterial sensitivities show it is sensitive to ciprofloxacin and, moreover, it was not used for treatment in this patient.  
❌ Mutated ribosomal subunit protein:
Incorrect: Resistance to aminoglycosides results from chromosomal mutation (by methylation) in the gene that codes for the target protein in the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome. This patient’s bacterial sensitivities show it is sensitive to gentamicin and, moreover, it was not used for treatment in this patient.  
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of hematuria. Over the past month, the patient has been urinating more frequently. Today, the patient has streaks of bright red blood in the urine. The patient is experiencing discomfort and pain with urination. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient works as a zoologist and travels around the world to conduct research. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the pelvic area but no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine microscopy reveals the findings below. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?  


Images reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of overseas travel presents with dysuria, hematuria, and polyuria. Urine microscopy reveals eggs with a terminal spine. These findings are suggestive of Schistosoma haematobium infection, which can be treated with praziquantel.  

Praziquantel is the first-line therapy against most infections caused by flukes (e.g. schistosoma species) and tapeworms. It is also a second-like agent in the treatment of neurocysticercosis.  

Praziquantel works by increasing the permeability of parasitic cellular membranes to calcium ions; thereby, leading to muscle paralysis and death. The drug is metabolized in the liver by cytochrome p450 enzymes, so inducers of this enzyme can decrease praziquantel’s effectiveness. Side effects of praziquantel are usually mild and may include headaches and fatigue.  



Option Analysis

❌ Melarsoprol:
Incorrect: Melarsoprol is an antiprotozoal agent that is used as a first-line treatment for sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei. In contrast, this patient's history and urine microscopy findings are more suggestive of Schistosoma haematobium infection.  
❌ Metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is used for the treatment of giardiasis, amebiasis, Helicobacter pylori infection, and trichomoniasis. None of these infections present with hematuria or dysuria. In contrast, this patient's history and urine microscopy findings are more suggestive of Schistosoma haematobium infection.  
❌ Artemisinin-based combination therapy:
Incorrect: Artemisinin-based combination therapy is used for the treatment of chloroquine-resistant malaria. Typical symptoms of malaria include high fevers, headaches, profuse sweating, chills, and nausea. Dysuria and hematuria are not typically seen.  
✅ Praziquantel:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Niclosamide:
Incorrect: Niclosamide is an anthelmintic drug that can be used to treat various tapeworm infections. Tapeworm infections typically cause gastrointestinal symptoms, as opposed to hematuria and dysuria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents to the obstetrics clinic at 28 weeks’ gestation with two days of dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency. There is no associated hematuria, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, or decreased fetal movement. Pregnancy to date has been uncomplicated. Her prior pregnancy was delivered via cesarean delivery at term for breech presentation. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/82 mmHg. The patient appears well, has no costovertebral tenderness, and no pooling on a speculum exam. Bedside testing for ruptured membranes is negative. Which of the following findings would warrant treatment with oral antibiotics?

choices.text: Red blood cells (RBCs) on urine microscopy
A hyperechoic focus with posterior shadowing in the bladder on ultrasound

questions.solution:
Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder that typically presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, or urinary incontinence. A pregnant patient with these symptoms should be evaluated with a urinalysis and urine culture. Empiric oral antibiotics are indicated when the urinalysis supports the diagnosis of acute cystitis, such as positive nitrites (produced by some uropathogens and highly specific for infection), positive leukocyte esterase (an enzyme produced by white blood cells), and pyuria (white blood cells in the urine).        

The diagnosis of acute cystitis is confirmed when the urine culture grows at least 100,000 CFU/mL of a single pathogen, and culture sensitivities should then guide any necessary adjustments to antimicrobial therapy. Additionally, some experts will also treat symptomatic patients whose cultures yield between 100 CFU/mL and 100,000 CFU/mL because of the higher risk of ascending infection and the morbidity associated with pyelonephritis during pregnancy.       

A renal ultrasound is reserved for those whose presentation and urinalysis suggest nephrolithiasis. However, it is not indicated solely for uncomplicated cystitis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nitrites on urinalysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: A febrile patient with urinary symptoms in pregnancy should be treated with intravenous antibiotics for presumed pyelonephritis, not oral therapy. 
❌ Red blood cells (RBCs) on urine microscopy:
Incorrect: Isolated microscopic hematuria without bacteriuria or other evidence of infection is more suggestive of nephrolithiasis and does not by itself justify antibiotics. 
❌ Hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Physiologic hydronephrosis is normal during pregnancy. Excessive hydronephrosis may indicate nephrolithiasis, which is managed with hydration and analgesics rather than antibiotics. 
❌ A hyperechoic focus with posterior shadowing in the bladder on ultrasound:
Incorrect: This would likely represent a renal calculus that has passed into the bladder. Nephrolithiasis is managed with hydration and analgesics rather than antibiotics.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old primigravid woman at 33 weeks’ gestation presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of worsening fever and right flank pain. There has been no increase in urinary frequency, though the patient already voids every hour and several times at night since entering the third trimester. There is no associated hematuria, loss of fluid, uterine contractions, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. On physical exam, there is right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. The cervix is closed, thick, and high on digital pelvic examination. Urinalysis results are shown below. In addition to intravenous (IV) fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?        
 Laboratory value     Result    
 Urinalysis    
 Color     Clear    
 Specific gravity     1.013    
 Glucose     Negative    
 Blood     Negative    
 Leukocyte esterase     Positive    
 Nitrites     Positive    
 Leukocytes     15/hpf    
 Erythrocytes     1-2/hpf    
 Casts     None
questions.solution:
Pregnant patients who present with fever, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and urinary symptoms (e.g., dysuria, frequency, urgency) and who have supportive laboratory findings (e.g., leukocyte esterase or nitrites on urinalysis, pyuria on microscopy, positive urine culture) can be diagnosed with pyelonephritis. Management consists of IV hydration and IV antibiotics. A urine culture should be obtained prior to administering antibiotics so that therapy can be tailored to the identified bacteria’s sensitivities.       

In pregnancy, pyelonephritis is associated with an increased risk of maternal sepsis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and preterm labor. For this reason, affected patients are admitted for inpatient care and treated with IV antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone, until they show signs of clinical improvement.        

Once symptoms improve and the patient has been afebrile for at least 24 hours, therapy may be switched to oral antibiotics to complete a 14-day course. If there is no improvement within 48 to 72 hours of initiating IV antibiotics, an evaluation for antibiotic resistance is indicated. A renal ultrasound is also often appropriate to exclude alternative pathology, such as an infected kidney stone that may require urologic intervention.   




Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous (IV) antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics are appropriate for acute cystitis or asymptomatic bacteriuria. However, this patient has a fever and flank pain, indicating the infection has spread to the upper urinary tract. IV antibiotics are now required. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) analgesics:
Incorrect: IV analgesics and hydration are used to treat nephrolithiasis, which typically presents without fever or positive nitrites and leukocyte esterase on urinalysis. While analgesics can help control pain in pyelonephritis, IV antibiotics remain the priority. 
❌ Alpha blocker:
Incorrect: Alpha blockers (antagonists) are often given in cases of nephrolithiasis to relieve ureteral spasm. However, this patient’s fever, flank pain, and urinalysis findings indicate pyelonephritis, which requires IV antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Renal ultrasound is indicated when nephrolithiasis is suspected, which typically presents with flank pain and hematuria without signs of infection. This patient’s fever, flank pain, and urinalysis findings suggest pyelonephritis, which requires IV antibiotic therapy.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and increased irritability for the past two days. His parent reports that he has had foul-smelling, dark urine. The patient has not had a cough, congestion, sore throat, or ear ache. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication. He was born at 35 weeks gestation. Family history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by chronic kidney disease and hypertension in the patient's mother. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears irritable and has suprapubic tenderness to palpation. Genitourinary examination shows uncircumcised male genitalia and a normal testicular examination. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Urinalysis findings are shown below. Which of the following factors places the patient at the highest risk of developing the likely underlying condition?  

Laboratory value
Result
Urinalysis

Color
Clear
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
negative
Blood
negative
Leukocyte esterase  
Large
Nitrites
Positive
Leukocytes
50-100/hpf  
Erythrocytes
1-2/hpf  
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent
Casts
none

choices.text: Family history of chronic kidney disease secondary to type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
This patient presents with irritability, fever, and suprapubic tenderness with associated foul-smelling urine. Urinalysis shows evidence of large leukocyte esterase with positive nitrites and increased leukocytes. Together, these findings are concerning for a urinary tract infection (UTI).

In the pediatric population, biologically male patients who are uncircumcised have a higher risk of urinary tract infections than do circumscribed patients. Female infants have a higher risk of UTIs than male patients. Patients with obstructive urologic abnormalities and those with vesicoureteral reflux are at increased risk of developing UTIs.

Urinary tract infection (UTI) is a common bacterial infection in children that can involve any part of the urinary tract and is usually caused by gastrointestinal flora, such as Escherichia coli. Clinical presentation often depends on the patient’s age. Young, non-verbal patients often present with fever, increased fussiness, poor feeding, or lethargy in the absence of associated infectious symptoms (e.g. cough, congestion, sore throat). Older, verbal patients may report dysuria, polyuria, hematuria, or, in the case of pyelonephritis, back or flank pain, nausea, and vomiting. Regardless of age, patients will often have foul-smelling, dark urine. Patients should be screened for risk factors and examined for signs of complicated disease such as costo-vertebral angle tenderness, dehydration, and signs of sepsis (e.g. skin mottling).  

Option Analysis

✅ Uncircumcised penis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Male sex:
Incorrect: Female sex, not male sex, is a known risk factor for the development of urinary tract infections.  
❌ Family history of chronic kidney disease secondary to type 2 diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: A family history of chronic kidney disease from type 2 diabetes mellitus is not a known risk factor for the development of urinary tract infections in pediatric patients.  
❌ Premature birth:
Incorrect: Premature birth is not a known risk factor for the development of urinary tract infections later in life.  
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Biological males who are less than 12 months of age are at increased risk of developing urinary tract infections than are older males.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of fever and vomiting for the past 2 days. The patient has had associated foul-smelling urine and dysuria. He is otherwise healthy and does not take daily medication. Temperature is 39°C (102°F), pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient has dry mucous membranes and reproducible left-sided costovertebral tenderness to palpation on physical examination. Genitourinary examination shows uncircumcised male genitalia and a normal testicular examination. A urinalysis is positive for nitrites and leukocyte esterase. Which of the following conditions is this patient most at risk of developing if he is not treated promptly?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of dysuria, fever, and vomiting with reproducible costo-vertabral angle tenderness. Together, these findings are concerning for pyelonephritis, a known complication of urinary tract infections in pediatric patients. The presence of nitrites and leukocyte esterase in urinalysis further support this diagnosis. Without prompt recognition and treatment, pediatric patients with untreated urinary tract infections can develop long-term complications including hypertension, renal scarring, and chronic kidney disease.

Urinary tract infection (UTI) is a common bacterial infection that can involve any part of the urinary tract. In children, UTIs are usually caused by gastrointestinal flora, such as Escherichia coli, that ascend into the bladder or kidneys, causing cystitis, pyelonephritis, or even urosepsis. The management of UTIs depends on the patient’s age; more specifically, whether they are older or younger than two months old.

Regardless of age, the acute management of unstable pediatric patients (e.g. urosepsis) with urinary tract infections requires close vital sign monitoring, hemodynamic support, as well as administration of intravenous fluids and empiric antibiotics. Urinalysis and microscopy should be done along with urine culture. Other diagnostic tests such as a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and renal imaging should be considered as well. In non-toilet trained children, a urine specimen should ideally be obtained via straight catheterization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Renal scarring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bronchopulmonary dysplasia:
Incorrect: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is a known consequence of prematurity and respiratory distress of the newborn. This condition is not associated with urinary tract infections.  
❌ Polycystic kidneys:
Incorrect: Polycystic kidneys result from an autosomal dominant inherited genetic condition. Urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis do not place patients at risk for polycystic kidneys.  
❌ Periorbital edema:
Incorrect: Periorbital edema may occur with nephritic syndrome from poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). This patient has no history or symptoms to suggest a recent streptococcal infection, and the urine sample does not show blood or protein which would be expected with PSGN.  
❌ Desquamating rash:
Incorrect: A desquamating rash may be seen with Stevens-Johnson syndrome, DRESS syndrome, certain skin infections, as well as after a streptococcal infection. A desquamating rash is not associated with urinary tract infections or pyelonephritis in pediatric patients.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of irritability and foul-smelling dark urine for two days. The patient’s parent reports that the patient has been tolerating oral intake without vomiting. The patient has no chronic medical conditions and has never taken antibiotics. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 167/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is crying but is consolable. Mucous membranes appear moist. Abdominal exam is normal. Cardiopulmonary and HEENT examinations are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows normal appearing female genitalia. A straight catheterization is performed with results shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic to initiate at this time?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Urinalysis

Color
Clear
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
negative
Blood
negative
Leukocyte esterase  
Large
Nitrites
Positive
Leukocytes
50-100/hpf  
Erythrocytes
1-2/hpf  
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent
Casts
none
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with irritability and foul-smelling, dark urine, with positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites detected in a urine sample, likely has a urinary tract infection (UTI) and should be treated with empiric antibiotics. For pediatric patients older than two months with uncomplicated urinary tract infections, the most appropriate first-line agent is a first generation cephalosporin like cephalexin.

The management approach for children with UTIs is to first determine whether the child should be treated as an inpatient or outpatient. The presence of factors such as age less than two months, signs of urosepsis, immunocompromised state, inability to tolerate oral hydration, lack of adequate outpatient follow up or failure to respond to outpatient therapy should prompt inpatient management. Patients like this one who can be managed as outpatients should be started on empiric antibiotic therapy while awaiting culture results.

In children over the age of two months, UTIs are usually caused by gastrointestinal flora such as Escherichia coli; therefore, the choice of antibiotic for empiric treatment should include coverage for this organism. Cephalosporins are the preferred therapy when no allergy to or recent use of cephalosporins exists. For patients like this one who are being treated as outpatients, a first-generation cephalosporin like cephalexin is preferred. Alternate agents available for patients over the age of two months when cephalosporins cannot be used include nitrofurantoin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, and TMP-SMX. Choice of antibiotic should be tailored to the results of the urine culture when it becomes available.  Follow-up assessment within 48 to 72 hours should be done for all children with UTIs since failure of outpatient therapy is a reason to consider changing the antibiotics or admission.

Genitourinary imaging should be considered, especially in young children with UTIs and in those with recurrent UTI.  Abnormalities of the genitourinary tract such as obstructive uropathy or vesicoureteral reflux may be the underlying reason for infection and would require additional work-up and management to prevent recurrence. Hydration therapy should be encouraged in all patients and antipyretics should be utilized as needed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cephalexin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin is not first-line treatment for uncomplicated urinary tract infections because of high rates of E. coli resistance.  
❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: Intravenous vancomycin may be used to treat urinary tract infections (UTIs) in patients who are found to have resistant gram-positive organisms. Vancomycin is not first-line empiric treatment for pediatric patients with UTIs, which are typically caused by E. coli , and should be treated with cephalosporins.  
❌ Clindamycin:
Incorrect: Clindamycin can be used to treat skin and soft tissue infections in pediatric patients; however, it is not first-line treatment for pediatric patients with urinary tract infections who should instead be treated empirically with cephalosporins.  
❌ Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid can be used to treat urinary tract infections in pediatric patients who have been treated with cephalosporins in the two months prior to presentation. Cephalexin is the preferred first-line agent for pediatric urinary tract infections in patients who have not recently used this class of medications.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to the primary care office with three days of dysuria. Her parents report that she has been urinating more frequently and had one episode of incontinence. Her urine has a foul odor. Parents have been working on potty training, and the child has held urine for extended periods of time. She attends preschool three days per week and plays outside most evenings. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respiratory rate is 22/min and blood pressure is 90/50 mmHg. Cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations are within normal limits. Abdominal exams reveal mild discomfort in the suprapubic region. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis (UA) is positive for leukocyte esterase with 10 red blood cells per high power field. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Antibiotics and repeat urinalysis in two weeks
Exercise avoidance and repeat urinalysis in three months
Laboratory evaluation including c-ANCA and p-ANCA
Computed tomography scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
This child presents with urinary frequency, urgency, dysuria, and foul urine odor, with urinalysis showing leukocyte esterase and hematuria. She likely has a urinary tract infection. Urinary tract infections are a common, transient cause of hematuria in children. The infection should be treated with antibiotics and the UA should be repeated twice (at least one week apart), to ensure that the hematuria is transient.

Common causes of transient hematuria in pediatric patients include urinary tract infections, exercise, and trauma (e.g., external source or iatrogenic cause such as cystoscopy or catheter placement). Also, menses can be mistaken for hematuria. When a patient presents with hematuria and one of these factors is present, the urinalysis should be repeated twice, at least one week apart, to ensure resolution of the presumptive cause. If the hematuria resolves, no further workup is needed. If the repeat urinalysis continues to be positive with over five red blood cells per high power field (RBC/HPF), the patient is considered to have persistent hematuria, requiring further workup. The morphology of the red blood cells can differentiate whether the process is glomerular, (dysmorphic red blood cells) or non-glomerular, (eumorphic red blood cells).

Option Analysis

✅ Antibiotics and repeat urinalysis in two weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Exercise avoidance and repeat urinalysis in three months:
Incorrect: Transient hematuria may be seen with heavy exercise or trauma; however, the normal play of a 3-year-old is not likely to cause hematuria. Furthermore, this child likely has a urinary tract infection, and the UA should be repeated in one to two weeks following treatment.
❌ Antibiotics and renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: A renal ultrasound may be indicated if two repeat urinalyses remain positive for eumorphic red blood cells. However, given that the cause of hematuria in this child is likely infectious, and there are no signs suggestive of renal pathology, the UA should be repeated twice before pursuing additional imaging.
❌ Laboratory evaluation including c-ANCA and p-ANCA:
Incorrect: Laboratory evaluation with c-ANCA and p-ANCA is useful for evaluating patients with persistent hematuria with dysmorphic red blood cells when the clinical setting is concerning for vasculitis. This child likely has transient hematuria caused by a urinary tract infection; therefore, she should be treated empirically for infection and have a repeat UA performed.
❌ Computed tomography scan of the abdomen:
Incorrect: A computed tomography scan of the abdomen can be used to evaluate for nephrolithiasis or abdominal masses. However, renal ultrasonography would be the first step in abdominal imaging for most conditions associated with hematuria, especially in a child where radiation exposure should be limited. However, for this child, no imaging is indicated.

questions.text: A 5 year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and irritability for two days. Her parent reports that the patient has had foul-smelling, dark urine. The patient has been given acetaminophen for fever control. She has a past medical history of an uncomplicated appendectomy at 4 months of age and was treated for otitis media two months ago with amoxicillin. She has a history of moderate developmental delay, and she is not yet toilet-trained. Temperature is 39°C (102°F), pulse is 124/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 99/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is crying. Mucous membranes appear moist. Cardiopulmonary and HEENT examinations are within normal limits. Suprapubic tenderness is present. Genitourinary examination shows normal-appearing female genitalia. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase. Which of the following is most likely to lead to misdiagnosis?

choices.text: Obtaining urine via a perineal bag

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of irritability, fever, and foul-smelling urine which is concerning for a urinary tract infection (UTI). In non-toilet-trained children, a urine specimen for culture should ideally be obtained via straight catheterization, as other methods of collection in this patient population such as obtaining urine via a perineal bag can lead to a contaminated specimen and misdiagnosis.

Evaluation of pediatric patients who present with a suspected UTI varies depending on the patient’s age and whether or not they are toilet-trained. Analysis of a urine sample is a cornerstone of diagnostic evaluation. A urine sample can be obtained via clean catch, straight catheterization, perineal bag, or suprapubic needle aspiration. When a urine culture is needed in addition to urinalysis, a clean sample is typically obtained via straight catheterization in non-toilet trained patients, as urine collected via bag specimen is often contaminated by skin flora and can thus only be used for urinalysis. Suprapubic needle aspiration is another option for obtaining a urine sample for culture, but this is a painful procedure that is not commonly used. A clean-catch sample can be obtained in toilet-trained children.

In addition to urinalysis and urine culture, the workup for infants less than 2 months of age who present with a fever and signs suggestive of a UTI (e.g., foul-smelling urine, poor oral intake or vomiting, suprapubic tenderness) should also include a complete blood count (CBC), c-reactive protein, and procalcitonin. Blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture may also be included as part of a neonatal sepsis evaluation.

On urinalysis, the presence of leukocyte esterase, white blood cells, nitrites, or bacteria suggests a UTI. The quantitative threshold for bacterial counts in the urine culture that is used to diagnose a UTI varies depending on the method of collection and ranges from over 10,000 colony-forming units per milliliter to over 100,000 CFU/mL depending on the source of the sample.  Consideration should be given to renal and bladder imaging, in young children especially, to identify abnormalities of the genitourinary tract or post-infectious sequelae such as renal scarring. Additional workup in children of any age may include laboratory studies such as a CBC and basic metabolic panel, with blood cultures if signs of urosepsis are present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtaining urine via a perineal bag:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtaining urine via straight catheterization:
Incorrect: Obtaining urine via straight catheterization is the preferred method, particularly in very young or non-toilet trained patients who are unable to provide a clean urine sample.  
❌ Recent antibiotic use:
Incorrect: Recent antibiotic use can potentially confound the results of a urine culture; however, it is less likely to be a factor in this patient given that she was treated with antibiotics two months prior.  
❌ History of appendicitis:
Incorrect: Appendicitis can result in sterile pyuria (the presence of white blood cells in urine and a negative urine culture). However, this patient’s history of appendicitis is remote, making this a less likely confounding factor.  
❌ Acetaminophen use:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen use is unlikely to be a confounding factor in the diagnosis of pediatric urinary tract infections as it does not affect the results of urinalysis and culture.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic due to intermittent blood in his urine. The patient first noticed it 3 months ago, and it is becoming more frequent. The patient has also unintentionally lost 20 pounds over the past 3 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and current medications include amlodipine and carvedilol. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 50 years. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen shows a 4 cm mass in the left kidney. A biopsy is taken and shows renal cell carcinoma. CT of the chest is subsequently performed and shows multiple metastatic lesions in the bilateral lungs. The patient is started on a medication that stimulates cytotoxic T-cell proliferation and activation. Which of the following medications is being given to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presented with gross hematuria and unintentional weight loss, has been diagnosed with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC typically occurs in patients older than 50 (median age around 64 years old), and is more common in men than women. Smoking is a known risk factor for RCC.    

Aldessleukin, a recombinant interleukin-2,  is an immunomodulating agent used in the treatment of metastatic RCC and melanoma. It exerts its antitumor effects by stimulating IL-2 receptors, leading to activation and proliferation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes and natural killer cells. This helps the immune system fight against cancerous cells. Recombinant IL-2 can also promote the secretion of secondary cytokines, further improving the immune response.  

The side effects of recombinant interleukin-2 are usually dose-dependent, and can be reversed with dose reduction or stopping the medication. These side effects include hypotension, peripheral edema, and weight gain. Additionally, some patients have experienced neurotoxicity or acute kidney injury as a result of using recombinant IL-2.  

Option Analysis

✅ Aldesleukin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Basiliximab:
Incorrect: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody against the interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor. By blocking IL-2R, it prevents the proliferation of lymphocytes and suppresses the immune response. 
❌ Anakinra:
Incorrect: Anakinra is an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist. It blocks and prevents the proliferation of lymphocytes and depresses their cytotoxic ability. 
❌ Infliximab:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody that works against soluble tumor necrosis factor-alpha. It suppresses the immune response and lymphocyte activation and is used in certain autoimmune disorders (e.g. Crohn’s disease)
❌ Etanercept:
Incorrect: Etanercept is a fusion protein that binds to and sequesters tumor necrosis factor alpha, thereby preventing its action in stimulating the immune response and leukocyte activation.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents to the emergency room with hematuria and generalized fatigue for the past month. The patient has not experienced abdominal pain, fever, dysuria, or increased frequency of micturition. However, he has experienced a 3.5 kg (9 lb) weight loss over the last month and loss of appetite. Family history is noncontributory. He has smoked 2-3 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis is shown below. Cystoscopy is performed and biopsy specimens are obtained. Molecular analysis of the cells reveals malignant features and high sensitivity to paclitaxel. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate therapeutic agent?

choices.text: Inhibits topoisomerase I and promotes DNA degradation
Inhibits polymerisation of microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation
Inhibits topoisomerase II and promotes DNA degradation
Hyperstabilizes microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation
Inhibits ribonucleotide reductase and reduces DNA synthesis

questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with painless hematuria, weight loss, loss of appetite, and a positive smoking history. This clinical vignette strongly suggests a urothelial malignancy unless proven otherwise and necessitates evaluation.

Taxanes (e.g. paclitaxel) are a group of chemotherapeutic agents that act as microtubule inhibitors. They are active during the M phase of the cell cycle. They hyper-stabilize polymerized microtubules that are involved in the mitotic spindle, effectively preventing spindle separation. As a result, anaphase and DNA replication are arrested. Since malignant cells replicate more frequently when compared to normal cells, they are more susceptible to microtubule inhibitors.

Taxanes such as paclitaxel are used for the treatment of a variety of solid tumors including breast, head, and neck, ovarian, lung, prostate, and bladder cancers. Use of taxanes can result in adverse effects including myelosuppression, neuropathy, and hypersensitivity.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibits topoisomerase I and promotes DNA degradation:
Incorrect: Topoisomerase I inhibitors include irinotecan and topotecan. By inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase I, these medications prevent DNA unwinding and arrest DNA replication.  
❌ Inhibits polymerisation of microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation:
Incorrect: Vinca alkaloids, such as vincristine and vinblastine are microtubule inhibitors. Vinca alkaloids bind to ꞵ-tubulin and inhibit microtubule polymerization. In contrast, taxanes work via a different mechanism of action.  
❌ Inhibits topoisomerase II and promotes DNA degradation:
Incorrect: Etoposide and teniposide are topoisomerase II inhibitors. Inhibition of topoisomerase II increases DNA degradation.  
✅ Hyperstabilizes microtubules and prevents mitotic spindle formation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits ribonucleotide reductase and reduces DNA synthesis:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea is an antineoplastic agent that is S-phase specific. The medication inhibits ribonucleotide reductase and thereby arrests the synthesis of pyrimidine bases of DNA. In contrast, paclitaxel works via a different mechanism of action.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for lower back pain. The pain started six months ago and is worse at night. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the lumbar region of the vertebral column. MRI of the lumbar spine shows neoplastic masses. On additional evaluation, the patient is found to have metastatic prostate cancer. The physician decides to start the patient on a medication that blocks testosterone receptors on the tumor cells. Which of the following side effects is this patient at risk for due to this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with metastatic prostate cancer is started on a testosterone receptor blocker, flutamide, as part of the treatment. Hepatotoxicity is a possible side effect of this medication.

Androgens stimulate the growth of the prostate cells and can also induce the growth of prostate cancer; therefore, anti-androgens used in managing prostate cancer inhibit tumor growth. Flutamide is one such anti-androgen that blocks testosterone receptors on the tumor cells, thereby inhibiting the proliferation of the tumor. Due to its anti-androgen effects, flutamide is also sometimes used in managing hirsutism in women and hair loss in men.

The most common side effect of flutamide is hot flashes, usually seen in more than 50% of the population. Also, decreased libido, vomiting, and gynecomastia can be seen. One of the most severe and feared side effects of flutamide is hepatotoxicity. It usually happens secondary to mitochondrial injury of hepatocytes, causing cholestatic hepatitis and, ultimately, hepatic failure. Therefore, patients with severe liver injury must avoid using flutamide.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hepatotoxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Certain medications (e.g., bleomycin, amiodarone) can cause pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect. It is not associated with flutamide.  
❌ Heart failure:
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones can increase the risk of inducing or worsening heart failure. Flutamide is not directly related to the development of heart failure.  
❌ Hemochromatosis:
Incorrect: Exogenous androgen abuse can lead to hemochromatosis. However, flutamide is a testosterone receptor blocker and does not cause hemochromatosis.  
❌ Nephrotoxicity:
Incorrect: Flutamide is not known to cause nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to an oncologist’s office for consultation following a biopsy of a recently diagnosed cancer. The patient was diagnosed with clear cell renal cell carcinoma of the left kidney. Which of the following would be an ideal therapy to inhibit the microvascular growth and angiogenesis which often accompanies clear cell renal cell carcinomas?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recently diagnosed clear cell renal cell carcinoma. Treatment for kidney tumors is multifaceted and includes possible radical nephrectomy, partial nephrectomy, or targeted therapy with various immunotherapies. This question is asking for a specific therapy that will block neovascularization and angiogenesis seen with cancer. In the pathophysiology of cancer, it is well known that cancer cells overexpress vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), which as the name suggests, promotes neovascularization in the tumor microenvironment. VEGF expression is associated with several different cancer types. Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets VEGF-A, preventing this process of neovascularization from taking place. Bevacizumab is also useful in preventing wet age-related macular degeneration from taking place, which is typically characterized by choroidal neovascularization. Side effects of bevacizumab include hemorrhage, blood clots, and impaired wound healing.  

A helpful mnemonic to remember the anti-angiogenic effects of bevacizumab is that it inhibits the growth of blood vessels. 

Option Analysis

❌ Transtuzumab :
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to HER2 receptors in breast and gastric cancers. 
❌ Imatinib:
Incorrect: Imatinib is a bcr-abl tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. 
❌ Hydroxyurea:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase used in the treatment of melanoma and treatment-resistant CML. 
❌ Tamoxifen:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. It has no effect on preventing micro vascularization and angiogenesis. 
✅ Bevacizumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the oncology clinic to discuss a recent diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. Medical history is otherwise significant for hypertension, for which the patient takes lisinopril. Family history is significant for renal cell carcinoma in the patient’s father. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. The patient asks the oncologist why his “immune system is not attacking the cancer.” The oncologist explains several immune system regulators, such as the programmed death-1 ligand and receptor (PDL1 and PD-1, respectively) and cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA-4). Which of the following correctly describes how the cancer cells could be evading the immune system?

choices.text: CD28 on cancer cells binds CTLA-4 on T-cells
CTLA-4 on cancer cells binds CD28 on T-cells
PD-1 ligands on cancer cells bind PD-1 receptors on immune cells
PD-1 receptors on cancer cells bind PD-1 ligands on immune cells
p53 protein upregulation by cancer cells

questions.solution:
There are many ways tumor cells can evade the immune system. Normally, the immune system has several “checkpoint” functions that help prevent it from attacking its cells. Immune cells, such as regulatory T-lymphocytes, play a crucial role in this process. Several examples of regulatory checkpoints include co-stimulation signals for activation, programmed cell death, and downregulation of T-lymphocytes. Tumor cells can exploit these by expressing molecules that prevent their destruction by downregulating these regulatory immune cells.

One common example is the programmed death-1 pathway. Normally the PD-1 ligand (PDL1) is expressed in cells such as T-cells and NK cells. It binds to the PD-1 receptor (PD-1) on activated T-cells and B-cells to downregulate activated T-cells while promoting regulatory T-cells. 

Over the last decade, many new immunotherapy medications have been developed and approved for use as immune checkpoint inhibitors in cancers. Several examples include CTLA-4 inhibitors (e.g. ipilimumab), PDL1 inhibitors (e.g. atezolizumab) and PD-1 inhibitors (e.g. nivolumab, pembrolizumab).   

Option Analysis

❌ CD28 on cancer cells binds CTLA-4 on T-cells :
Incorrect: CD28 is a receptor found on T-cells that binds to CD80 (B7) for co-stimulatory signaling activation. CTLA-4 competes with CD28 to downregulate T-cell activation. CD28 does not bind to CTLA-4 (they are homologous receptors). 
❌ CTLA-4 on cancer cells binds CD28 on T-cells :
Incorrect: CD28 is a receptor found on T-cells that binds to CD80 (B7) for co-stimulatory signaling activation of T-cells. CTLA-4 competes with CD28 to downregulate T-cell activation. CD28 does not bind to CTLA-4 (they are homologous receptors). 
✅ PD-1 ligands on cancer cells bind PD-1 receptors on immune cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ PD-1 receptors on cancer cells bind PD-1 ligands on immune cells :
Incorrect: Cancer cells generally produce the PD-1 ligand, which binds to PD-1 receptors on T-cells, downregulating their activity. PDL1 expression on tumor cells can often be measured.  
❌ p53 protein upregulation by cancer cells :
Incorrect: p53 is a regulatory protein involved in DNA repair, apoptosis, and others. In general, it has anti-cancer properties (as it does things such as inhibit tumor angiogenesis).

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for a well child visit. She has been meeting all developmental milestones. Vitals are within normal range. The patient is well-appearing and cooperative. Physical examination reveals a mass in the left abdomen. A CT scan is performed and shows a unilateral heterogeneous renal mass. A biopsy is taken, and the patient is diagnosed with a stage II Wilms tumor. The tumor is resected, and the patient is started on a chemotherapeutic agent that works by binding with DNA and preventing RNA synthesis. The new agent does not interfere with topoisomerase activity. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with Wilms tumor, also termed nephroblastoma, and started on actinomycin D.

Actinomycin D is an antitumor antibiotic that intercalates with DNA and prevents DNA-dependent RNA polymerase from binding, thereby inhibiting RNA synthesis. This, in turn, halts RNA protein synthesis, ultimately leading to cellular arrest and inhibition of cellular division. In addition, actinomycin D can generate free radicals to cause DNA strand breaks. Actinomycin D is frequently used to treat pediatric tumors, such as Wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, and Ewing sarcoma.

Side effects of actinomycin D include bone marrow suppression, alopecia, as well as hepatotoxicity. Liver injury associated with actinomycin D can range from asymptomatic elevation of liver enzymes, which is usually transient and resolves without intervention, to fulminant liver injury, which can be severe and fatal.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hematuria:
