Incorrect: Hemorrhagic cystitis is a known complication of cyclophosphamide. It usually presents with hematuria, dysuria, and suprapubic pain. It is not a side effect of this medication.  
✅ Elevation of liver enzymes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral sensory neuropathy:
Incorrect: Chemotherapeutic agents such as paclitaxel, cisplatin, and vincristine are associated with neurotoxicity, which usually manifests as peripheral neuropathy. However, this patient was most likely started on actinomycin D. Actinomycin D does not typically cause peripheral neuropathy.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Pulmonary fibrosis is a side effect of the chemotherapeutic agents bleomycin and busulfan. It is not a side effect of this medication.  
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Doxorubicin is known to cause irreversible cardiotoxicity. This can result in dilated cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Although doxorubicin can intercalate with DNA, this medication also works by inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase II.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man admitted to the inpatient wards presents with hematuria. He has not had dysuria, straining, polyuria, abdominal pain, or fever. His medical history includes chronic lymphocytic leukemia, for which he underwent a bone marrow transplant two weeks ago, type II diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain. Before his transplant, he was treated with an antineoplastic drug that induces DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following could have prevented this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Aggressive hydration to prevent ureteric calculus formation
Treatment with penicillin to prevent glomerulonephritis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hematuria following initiation of a chemotherapeutic regimen suggestive of hemorrhagic cystitis secondary to cyclophosphamide use.  

Hemorrhagic cystitis, following the use of nitrogen mustards like cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide, is an inflammatory process induced by a toxic metabolite called acrolein. The liver metabolizes Cyclophosphamide, and acrolein is formed as a metabolic product. This substance is then filtered by the kidneys and concentrated in the bladder, promoting proinflammatory cytokines, generating reactive oxygen species, and producing nitric oxide. These compounds damage the urothelium, resulting in hemorrhage and edema. Forced saline diuresis, aggressive hydration, and pretreatment with MESNA, a neuroprotective agent, are indicated in all patients receiving cyclophosphamide. Mesna acts as a  thiol compound with a sulfhydryl donor that binds to acrolein, creating an inert thioether excreted in the urine.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pretreatment with a sulfhydryl donor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cessation of analgesics :
Incorrect: Analgesic nephropathy can present with hematuria in patients with a history of chronic pain and overuse of NSAIDs. Additional symptoms include flank pain and investigations that reveal azotemia. 
❌ Aggressive hydration to prevent ureteric calculus formation:
Incorrect: Nephrolithiasis typically involves ureteric colic (radiating pain to the groin), nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. Isolated hematuria is unlikely to stem from a diagnosis of ureteric colic. 
❌ Treatment with penicillin to prevent glomerulonephritis :
Incorrect: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis follows a streptococcal pharyngeal/skin infection and is prevented by the administration of penicillin. The most common clinical findings include hematuria, hypertension, and a urinalysis demonstrating dysmorphic red blood cells and red blood cell casts. 
❌ Screening renal ultrasound :
Incorrect: ADPKD or renal anatomic defects can present with hematuria, hypertension, flank pain, and a dilated pelvicalyceal system on ultrasound. Screening renal ultrasound is indicated in patients >18 years of age with a positive family history of ADPKD. Without a positive family history, a renal screening ultrasound is not indicated.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man admitted to the inpatient wards presents with hematuria. He has not had dysuria, straining, polyuria, abdominal pain, or fever. His medical history includes chronic lymphocytic leukemia, for which he underwent a bone marrow transplant two weeks ago, type II diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain. Before his transplant, he was treated with an antineoplastic drug that induces DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following findings are expected on urinalysis?

choices.text: Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  +3 Absent Fatty castsEpithelial cells with oval fat bodies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hematuria following initiation of a chemotherapeutic regimen suggestive of hemorrhagic cystitis secondary to cyclophosphamide use.   

Cyclophosphamide is nitrogen mustard used for conditioning before hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT). Its mechanism of action involves the creation of cross-links between interstrand guanine bases of DNA, resulting in DNA damage and impairment of replication and repair. Cyclophosphamide is associated with adverse effects, including alopecia, GI disturbances, myelosuppression, hemorrhagic cystitis, gonadal toxicity, infertility, teratogenic effects, and SIADH.  

Hemorrhagic cystitis, following the use of nitrogen mustards like cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide, is an inflammatory process induced by a toxic metabolite called acrolein. The liver metabolizes Cyclophosphamide, and acrolein is formed as a metabolic product. This substance is then filtered by the kidneys and concentrated in the bladder, where it promotes production of proinflammatory cytokines, generates reactive oxygen species, and production of nitric oxide. These compounds damage the urothelium, resulting in hemorrhage and edema. Forced saline diuresis, aggressive hydration, and pretreatment with MESNA are indicated in all patients receiving cyclophosphamide.  

Option Analysis

❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent  White blood cell casts  White blood cells  :
Incorrect: WBC casts in conjunction with clinical findings of fever, dysuria, and flank pain suggest pyelonephritis. 
✅  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent Absent Erythrocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  +3 Absent Fatty castsEpithelial cells with oval fat bodies:
Incorrect: Proteinuria, fatty casts, and oval fat bodies indicate a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome. 
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent PresentRed blood cell castsNone:
Incorrect:  Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can result in the presence of red blood cell casts and dysmorphic red blood cells. 
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent Absent Envelope-shaped crystals, Erythrocytes:
Incorrect:  Envelope-shaped crystals are indicative of calcium oxalate calculi.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient complains of pain on the left side of the chest that gets worse on deep breathing. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising and tenderness over the left posterior chest wall. The spinal range of motion is normal, and there is no midline tenderness. The gross motor and neurological examination is within normal limits. Plain chest radiograph reveals a left-sided 12th rib fracture. This patient is at increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient with a left 12th rib fracture is at risk of left kidney laceration.   

The chest comprises 12 rib bones on each side of the body. Each rib attaches to the spine at the back of the body and then travels around to the front of the chest. The top 7 ribs attach to the sternum, the 8th to 10th ribs attach to the ribs above via cartilage, and the 11th and 12th ribs are known as ‘floating’ ribs as they are unattached at the front of the chest.   

Rib fractures are the most common injury sustained in blunt thoracic trauma. Fractures may cause localized pain, crepitus, pain with inspiration, dyspnea, and may even cause pneumothorax or hemothorax. The left 12th rib overlies the parietal pleura medially and the left kidney laterally. Therefore, the distal tip of the left rib can displace into the retroperitoneum and lacerate the left kidney.   

Option Analysis

❌ Brachial plexus:
Incorrect: The brachial plexus extends from the spinal cord, through the cervicoaxillary canal in the neck, over the first rib, and into the armpit. It is susceptible to injury in cases of 1st-3rd rib fractures.  
❌ Subclavian artery:
Incorrect: The subclavian artery travels laterally, passing between anterior and middle scalene muscles, with the anterior scalene on its anterior side and the middle scalene on its posterior. As the subclavian artery crosses the lateral border of the first rib, it becomes the axillary artery. It would not be affected by 12th rib fractures.  
✅ Left kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pancreas:
Incorrect: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that stretches from behind the stomach to the left upper abdomen near the spleen. It overlies the body of the second lumbar vertebrae. It is most susceptible to injury with a crushing abdominal trauma.   
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: The spleen is underneath the left part of the diaphragm and the ninth, tenth, and eleventh ribs on the left side. It is less likely to be injured in 12th rib fracture.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after colliding with a car while riding his bicycle. He was struck from the right side by the vehicle and thrown from his bike. His Glasgow Coma Scale is 15, and he is reporting severe pelvic pain. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 118/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. There is diffuse ecchymosis across the right lateral and anterior pelvis. The abdomen is distended and there is suprapubic tenderness. Compression over the iliac crests produces pain and reveals vertical instability on the right side.  Blood is present at the urethral meatus. IV access is obtained. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This trauma patient presents with ecchymosis, abdominal distention, suprapubic tenderness, pelvic instability and blood at the urethral meatus suggestive of bladder and urethral injuries in the setting of a pelvic fracture. The patient’s injuries are likely causing significant internal bleeding given the findings of hypotension and tachycardia. Application of a pelvic binder can assist in tamponade of ongoing hemorrhage, while additional workup is pursued.    

Bladder injury in the setting of blunt pelvic trauma is often accompanied by concurrent injuries such as pelvic fracture and urethral injury. A bladder injury alone does not typically cause hemodynamic instability. Signs such as hypotension and tachycardia should raise suspicion of internal bleeding from a pelvic fracture. For trauma patients, the first priority is always stabilization with ABCDE assessment. Once the airway is secure and IV access established, a GCS should be calculated, and the cervical spine should be stabilized. Placement of a urinary catheter is the next step in a suspected bladder injury. A transurethral catheter is the standard approach, except for cases of suspected urethral injury. Signs suggestive of urethral injury include blood at the urethral meatus, bruising along the penis or perineum, high-riding prostate, and inability to pass urine. In these instances, the catheter should be placed suprapubically. 

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic binder placement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Transurethral catheter insertion:
Incorrect: A transurethral catheter should not be used when a urethral injury is suspected. This patient has evidence of blood at the urethral meatus which is a sign of urethral injury; therefore, the catheter should be placed suprapubically. 
❌ CT of the pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT of the pelvis is indicated for patients with suspected bladder injury; however, this patient has signs of hemodynamic instability suggestive of ongoing bleeding and signs of pelvic fracture. Placement of a pelvic binder takes precedence as it may slow bleeding.
❌ Antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are indicated in the management of a suspected bladder injury; however, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of pelvic fracture, and placement of a pelvic binder takes precedence.
❌ Retrograde urethrogram:
Incorrect: A retrograde urethrogram is indicated for patients with a suspected urethral injury; however, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of pelvic fracture, necessitating placement of a pelvic binder.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the office because of blood in her urine. The patient reports intermittent painless hematuria associated with mild to moderate left lumbar pain and nausea for the last three months. She does not have dysuria, urinary frequency, or urinary urgency. Past medical history is significant for major depression, and the patient reports that she has lost a lot of weight over the past few months. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a nontender, nondistended abdomen. Lungs and cardiovascular examination are within normal limits. Urinalysis shows 15–20 Er/Hpf and no proteinuria. An abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a recent history of significant weight loss presents with intermittent gross hematuria and lumbar pain. The abdominal CT scan demonstrates left renal vein compression at its distal segment between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery with mild proximal dilatation. In combination, this presentation is consistent with nutcracker syndrome (NCS).  

NCS occurs when the left renal vein, which drains blood from the left kidney, becomes squeezed between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and abdominal aorta. Normally, the aortomesenteric angle (between SMA and aorta) is around 45 degrees, with the renal vein cushioned by a bit of fat in the mesentery. If there is significant weight loss which shrinks the mesenteric fat, this angle is reduced, and the arteries begin to pinch the left renal vein, causing renal hypertension. Over time, the high pressures cause small breaks in the renal blood vessels. Patients typically present with gross hematuria and left flank pain that may improve or worsen depending on positioning.  

Since the left gonadal vein drains via the left renal vein, nutcracker syndrome can also result in left testicular pain in males or left lower quadrant pain in females, especially during intercourse and during menstruation. An unusual manifestation of NCS includes varicocele formation and varicose veins in the lower limbs.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ureteric stone:
Incorrect: Ureteric stones lie within the ureter at any point from the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) to the vesicoureteric junction (VUJ). They are the classic cause of renal colic-type abdominal pain. Although it may cause hematuria and flank pain, CT scan would show an opacity in the ureter, rather than left renal vein compression.  
❌ Pelvic congestion syndrome:
Incorrect: Pelvic congestion syndrome in women is believed to be due to enlarged veins in the lower abdomen secondary to blood flowing back into pelvic veins.The condition may cause chronic pain, such as a constant dull ache, which can be worsened by standing or sexual intercourse. Gross hematuria is typically absent.  
❌ Superior mesenteric artery syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome occurs when the transverse portion of the duodenum is entrapped between the SMA and aorta, causing symptoms of bowel obstruction. Gross hematuria is not typically seen.  
✅ Nutcracker syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Renal artery stenosis:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis is the narrowing of one or both of the renal arteries, most often caused by atherosclerosis or fibromuscular dysplasia. Patients typically present with elevated blood pressure that is not controlled by medications. Physical examination may show a bruit over the renal artery on auscultation. This patient’s vitals are within normal limits.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an accident that occurred while riding an all-terrain vehicle. He was traveling on a wooded path at 20 mph when he hit a rock and was thrown from the vehicle. He has severe pelvic pain and gross hematuria. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 146/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He appears in distress but is awake, alert, and oriented. There are ecchymoses across the anterior pelvis and laxity with pelvic stability testing. Suprapubic tenderness is noted. There is no blood at the urethral meatus.  FAST scan is negative for free fluid. A CT in the portal venous phase shows a pelvic ring fracture with bony fragments extending into the extraperitoneal space. There is no visible contrast extravasation from the bladder. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s gross hematuria in the setting of a pelvic fracture is highly suspicious for a bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the best way to detect a bladder injury, as a standard CT does not concentrate enough contrast in the urine to adequately evaluate the integrity of the bladder.    

Patients with pelvic injury and gross hematuria should have dedicated imaging to evaluate for bladder and urethral injury. A standard CT is often performed initially as part of trauma management; however, a retrograde cystogram is needed to definitively characterize a bladder injury and a retrograde urethrogram is needed to diagnose a urethral injury. These studies involve direct injection of contrast dye into the bladder or urethra, followed by X-ray, fluoroscopy, or CT.  Extravasation of dye into the perivesical space is diagnostic for an extraperitoneal bladder injury, which occurs below the peritoneal reflection; whereas dye detected within the peritoneal cavity indicates an intraperitoneal bladder injury, usually at the bladder dome. Injury of the urethra can be diagnosed when contrast dye is seen outside of the urethral tract.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retrograde cystography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MRI of the pelvis:
Incorrect: An MRI of the pelvis may be needed for surgical planning but is not part of the initial workup for a patient with a suspected bladder or urethral injury.
❌ Cystoscopy:
Incorrect: Cystoscopy may be helpful for surgical planning regarding urethral or bladder injury repair but is not a part of the initial diagnostic workup. Retrograde cystography serves as the best way to assess the location and extent of a bladder injury in the emergency setting.
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: Exploratory laparotomy may be necessary when imaging fails to diagnose the location of a bladder injury or when bleeding or signs of instability require urgent attention. 
❌ CTA of the pelvis:
Incorrect: Angiography and embolization may be necessary for unstable patients with active bleeding from a pelvic fracture.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pelvic and abdominal pain after falling from a 10-foot ladder. He had been painting his house and needed to urinate but ignored the urge in order to finish his work. He has had gross hematuria since the fall but has no other injuries. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 148/90 mmHg and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, he is awake, alert, and oriented. The abdomen appears distended with diffuse tenderness and guarding with palpation. There is no blood at the urethral meatus and the prostate is in normal position. The pelvis is stable without laxity or crepitus. Free fluid in the abdomen is noted on Focused Assessment With Sonography in Trauma (FAST) and CT cystogram confirms contrast extravasation from the bladder into the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is the best plan for definitive management?

choices.text: Antibiotics and delayed surgical repair with reconstruction

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall for evaluation of abdominal pain, distention, guarding, and gross hematuria suggestive of a bladder injury. Contrast extravasation into the peritoneal cavity on CT cystogram is diagnostic for an intraperitoneal bladder injury, which should be treated with antibiotics and prompt surgical repair in this stable patient. The patient’s full bladder at the time of trauma likely contributed to the rupture.    

An intraperitoneal bladder injury involves disruption at the dome of the bladder, which communicates directly with the peritoneal cavity. Leakage of urine into the peritoneum can lead to acute renal failure and sepsis. Early recognition and prompt surgical management are necessary.    

When a bladder injury occurs below the peritoneal reflection, it is referred to as extraperitoneal and urine will leak into the perivesical space. Simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries can be managed conservatively with catheter drainage and antibiotics. The catheter should be placed suprapubically if a concurrent urethral injury is suspected, as the insertion of a transurethral catheter can worsen the injury.    

Complex extraperitoneal bladder injuries should be managed surgically and include injuries located at the bladder neck, injuries that involve fragments of bone or damage to the rectum or vagina, and injuries that fail to respond to a trial of catheter drainage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Antibiotics and immediate surgical repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antibiotics and suprapubic catheter placement:
Incorrect: Simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries can be managed with antibiotics and urethral catheter drainage; however, this patient has an intraperitoneal rupture which must be repaired surgically.
❌ Transurethral catheter and bed rest:
Incorrect: Urethral catheter drainage can be used to manage simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries; however, this patient has an intraperitoneal rupture which must be repaired surgically.
❌ Antibiotics and delayed surgical repair with reconstruction:
Incorrect: Delayed surgical repair may be needed for a patient with an intraperitoneal bladder rupture who is too unstable to undergo surgery. This patient is hemodynamically stable, therefore he should have immediate surgical repair.
❌ Suprapubic catheter and cystoscopy:
Incorrect:  Urethral catheter drainage can be used to manage simple extraperitoneal bladder injuries; however, this patient has signs of an intraperitoneal rupture which must be repaired surgically. Cystoscopy is not required for the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a skin lesion. He does not have pain, itching, or discharge from the lesion. He states that it has been present since birth, and he has not noted any significant changes in its appearance. Past medical history includes testicular cancer treated with orchiectomy five years ago. Family history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows a 0.5 cm, single, well-demarcated reddish-brown papule inferior to the left breast. Both breasts and axilla appear normal. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis
Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery
Failed involution of the mammary ridge

questions.solution:
The most common congenital breast condition in males and females is polythelia (supernumerary nipples), which results from the mammary ridge's failure to involution. The most common site for accessory nipples lies just inferior to the normal breast. Accessory nipples are usually asymptomatic, and excision is not required.  

Another related condition is polymastia (supernumerary breasts). This condition refers to more petite than usual breasts that consist of only a rudimentary nipple and areola (often mistaken for a mole). Supernumerary breasts can appear anywhere along a line that extends from the axilla to the groin along the milk line (location of embryonic mammary crest cells from which the breasts develop). The most common site for polymastia is the lower axilla.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis:
Incorrect: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis can result in athelia, for example, the absence of a nipple or amastia (i.e. absence of breast tissue). This patient’s presentation is consistent with an accessory nipple.  
❌ Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery presents with tender, palpable abscesses over the periphery of the areola. This patient’s breast examination is unremarkable.  
❌ Abnormal response to gonadal hormones:
Incorrect: Abnormal response to gonadal hormones results in spontaneous overgrowth of breast tissue. Overgrowth may be unilateral or symmetric (more common) and begins around puberty. This patient’s breasts appear normal.  
✅ Failed involution of the mammary ridge  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes:
Incorrect: Benign melanocytic nevi result from the clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes. They are usually small or medium-sized, solitary, and may occur anywhere on the skin. This patient’s examination findings are suggestive of an accessory nipple.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the gynecologist for a well-patient examination. She has no current complaints. She is sexually active with one biologically male partner, and they use condoms sporadically. She has no chronic medical conditions and does not take daily medications. She has received the meningococcal vaccine, two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine, an annual influenza vaccine, and Tdap within the past 10 years. She has not previously received an HPV vaccine. Her family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 98% on room air, and BMI is 28. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following interventions is indicated at this time?
questions.solution:
This 18-year-old patient who has not previously had an HPV vaccine should receive the vaccination series at this time. HPV vaccination can begin as early as age nine and is recommended for everyone up to age 26. The vaccine may be offered up until age 45 depending on patient risk factors and preferences. The HPV vaccine is administered as a series of two or three injections depending on patient factors, including age and immunocompetence.  

The recommended components of a well-patient examination are dependent on the age of the patient as well as risk factors the patient may have for various conditions. The patient’s medical history, social history, and family history will determine a significant portion of their risk factors. In addition to basic screening and counseling for all patients, an 18-year-old should be offered the HPV vaccine if not already given and have a discussion regarding birth control methods. Biological females should be counseled on supplementation with folic acid, and counseling (as well as screening, if indicated) for sexually transmitted infections. Hearing and vision testing can also be considered. Anticipatory guidance regarding cervical cancer screening at age 21 can be offered as well as reviewing safety topics, such as drug, tobacco, and alcohol use; distracted driving; skin cancer risk factors; seatbelt use; and relationship safety.



Option Analysis

✅ HPV vaccine:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Cervical cancer screening:
Incorrect: Cervical cancer screening begins at age 21 and continues until age 65. This patient is not old enough to require cervical cancer screening despite being sexually active. 
❌ Screening mammography:
Incorrect: Screening mammography begins at age 40 unless there is a family history of a first-degree relative with breast cancer diagnosed before the age of 50. If so, then screening should begin 10 years prior to that relative’s age at the time of diagnosis. This patient does not have an indication for early screening.
❌ BRCA testing:
Incorrect: BRCA testing is typically done after age 17 when indicated but is dependent on the patient’s risk factors. Indications for BRCA testing include a known family history of BRCA-positive status, a personal or family history of certain types of cancers, or the presence of certain genetic conditions. This patient does not have risk factors that would require BRCA testing. 
❌ Herpes zoster vaccine:
Incorrect: Herpes zoster vaccine is indicated for all adults age 50 and over as well as adults age 19 and over who are immunocompromised. This patient does not meet the age or risk-factor requirements for herpes zoster vaccination.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of irregular menstrual cycles for the past year. She reports intervals ranging from 4 weeks to 3 months, as well as frequent hot flashes, night sweats, and recent onset of difficulty sleeping. She notes vaginal dryness and occasional pain with vaginal intercourse. Her medical history includes hyperthyroidism from Graves disease, treated with radioactive iodine ablation 10 years ago. Her only medication is levothyroxine. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 25 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing woman. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following findings is most likely to be identified on physical examination?  

Estradiol
<30 pg/mL  
Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)  
65 mU/mL (60 U/L)  
Luteinizing hormone  
50 mU/mL (60 U/L)  
Testosterone, free  
25 ng/dL  
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)  
2.3 μU/mL (2.3 mU/L)  
Prolactin
18 ng/mL (18 µg/L)  
Human chorionic gonadotropin  
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms associated with perimenopause (e.g., hot flashes, night sweats, dyspareunia, vaginal dryness, insomnia) and irregular menstrual cycles. Laboratory studies of secondary causes of amenorrhea are negative. This patient has been experiencing dyspareunia and vaginal dryness which are frequently associated with perimenopause and menopause. She is most likely to have evidence of vaginal/vulvar atrophy on physical exam which is thinning and drying of the vagina secondary to decreased estrogen that can lead to symptoms of dyspareunia and vaginal dryness.

Perimenopause occurs in women from the time they start having menopausal symptoms until one year after the cessation of menses, regardless of the patient’s age. Symptoms include abnormal uterine bleeding, vasomotor symptoms such as hot flashes and night sweats, vaginal or vulvar dryness and itching, dyspareunia, sleep disturbances, and changes in mood and cognition. Patients with genitourinary syndrome can have frequent urinary tract infections.  

Option Analysis

❌ Enlarged, multinodular thyroid:
Incorrect: Hot flashes, heat intolerance, and insomnia can be seen in hyperthyroidism secondary to toxic multinodular thyroid goiter. However, this would be unlikely in this patient who has had radioactive iodine ablation with the aim of destroying the thyroid gland. Also, she now has normal TSH levels on replacement therapy.  
❌ Bitemporal hemianopsia:
Incorrect: Bitemporal hemianopsia can be seen in patients with prolactinoma if a pituitary adenoma compresses the optic chiasm. Prolactinomas can cause secondary amenorrhea. However, this patient has a normal prolactin level, making a pituitary adenoma unlikely.  
❌ Delayed deep-tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: Delayed deep-tendon reflexes may be seen in hypothyroidism, which can cause irregular menstrual cycles and amenorrhea. However, this patient has a normal TSH level on replacement therapy. Vaginal/vulvar atrophy is more likely in this perimenopausal woman who has dyspareunia and vaginal dryness.  
❌ Galactorrhea:
Incorrect: Galactorrhea can be seen secondary to a pituitary adenoma which may also cause amenorrhea. However, this patient has a normal prolactin level, making a pituitary adenoma unlikely. Vaginal/vulvar atrophy is more likely in this perimenopausal woman who has dyspareunia and vaginal dryness.  
✅ Vaginal/vulvar atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for a well-patient gynecologic examination. She has no significant past medical history, and her medications include a daily prenatal vitamin and an oral contraceptive pill. She lives in a single-family home in the United States of America, which she has owned with her spouse for ten years. She has never traveled outside of the country. She has never been pregnant. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day since age 18 and consumes approximately three alcoholic beverages per week. Her family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 98% on room air, and BMI is 22. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following clinical conditions should be screened for in this patient?
questions.solution:
All adults should be screened for depression at their well-patient examination, regardless of age and risk factors. Pregnant, post-partum, and older adults are included in this screening recommendation. A validated questionnaire should be used for screening, and a positive screening test should prompt further evaluation and consideration of treatment with counseling with or without medical management.  

There are many standard screening tests that should be included in all well-patient gynecological visits; some vary depending on the patient's age and risk factors. Basic preventative care should focus on discussing substance use (including tobacco, alcohol, and illicit drugs), mental health, contraception, interpersonal and domestic violence, obesity, urinary incontinence, sexually transmitted infections, age-appropriate immunizations, and cancer screenings. The history and physical can narrow down which additional screenings may be indicated, such as diabetes, tuberculosis, and BRCA testing as well as which cancer screenings are indicated. The 10-year risk of a cardiovascular event should be calculated as patients aged 40 to 75 with a 10% risk or greater and one or more cardiovascular risk factors should be prescribed a statin.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Depression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diabetes:
Incorrect: Diabetes screening is indicated every three years beginning at age 35 for patients who have risk factors, such as obesity or a history of gestational diabetes. This patient does not meet criteria for diabetes screening.
❌ Tuberculosis:
Incorrect: Patients who would benefit from tuberculosis screening include those who have immigrated from countries with increased prevalence of tuberculosis and those living in high-risk congregate settings, such as homeless shelters, correctional facilities, or long-term care facilities. This patient does not meet criteria for tuberculosis screening.
❌ Colorectal cancer:
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer screening should begin at age 45 unless the patient has a family history of a first-degree relative with colorectal cancer diagnosed before the age of 50. If so, then screening should begin at age 40 or 10 years prior to that relative’s age at the time of diagnosis. This patient does not meet criteria for colorectal cancer screening at this time.
❌ Lung cancer:
Incorrect: Lung cancer screening is recommended for adults aged 50 to 80 years old who have a 20 pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. This patient does not meet the age or pack-year duration for lung cancer screening at this time.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for her yearly well-check. She has no current complaints. Her last colonoscopy was five years ago, mammogram six months ago, and HPV/Pap co-test three years ago: all were normal. She has a smoking history of 15 pack years and quit 20 years ago. Her family history is significant for Parkinson disease in her father. She no longer has menstrual periods. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 98% on room air, and BMI is 24. Physical examination is unremarkable. Calculated FRAX score is 13% and Framingham risk score is 7%. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal patient with a history of smoking has a FRAX score over 8.4% and should be offered osteoporosis screening with a DEXA scan. Normally, osteoporosis screening does not start in biological females until age 65; however, patients who are younger than 65 with increased risk of fractures should have their risk measured by a clinical risk assessment tool, such as FRAX. Patients should begin screening if their score is > 8.4%.   

Osteoporosis screening is an important part of the well-patient assessment. The goal of the FRAX clinical assessment tool is to risk-stratify how likely a patient is to have a major osteoporotic fracture in the next 10 years. Values above 8.4% indicate that the patient has a higher risk than the reference cohort (White women 65 years of age and older), and the patient should not wait until 65 to be screened. Factors taken into account when calculating the FRAX score include previous fracture history, parental fracture history, low body weight, smoking, glucocorticoid use, rheumatoid arthritis, secondary osteoporosis, alcohol consumption, and prior bone mineral density score of the femoral neck, if available. Follow-up intervals for the DEXA scan are dependent on the findings of the initial test as well as patient risk factors, but most screening guidelines recommend that a DEXA scan should not be repeated more frequently than every two years.  

Option Analysis

✅ DEXA scan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ HPV/Pap co-test:
Incorrect: HPV/Pap co-testing is recommended every five years for women aged 30-65 years. This patient is currently up-to-date on her cervical cancer screening.
❌ Mammography:
Incorrect: Mammography is recommended either annually or biennially depending on the guideline used. The decision regarding screening frequency should include shared decision making with the patient. This patient had a normal mammogram six months ago and would not be due for another mammogram at this time regardless of the guideline used.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: The interval for colorectal cancer screening with colonoscopy is 10 years. This patient is up-to-date on colorectal cancer screening.
❌ Low-dose chest CT:
Incorrect: Lung cancer screening using low-dose chest CT is recommended for adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a 20 pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. This patient does not meet the pack-year duration or the time since quitting to have lung cancer screening done.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation for over 1-year of worsening hot flashes and amenorrhea. She reports that the hot flashes during the day and night have significantly impacted her quality of life and disrupted her life. She has frequently had to call out of work due to feeling exhausted after not sleeping at night. During the day she has had to miss meetings at work because of her hot flashes. Her medical history is significant for a total hysterectomy performed 5 years ago for benign fibroids. She has no personal or family history of cardiovascular disease, venous thromboembolism, or breast cancer. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is open to taking any type of medication that will help. Vital signs are within normal limits. BMI is 24 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Lifestyle modifications and re-evaluation in 6 months

questions.solution:
This patient is having significant vasomotor menopausal symptoms (hot flashes and night sweats) that are significantly interfering with her normal functioning. She has a history of a total hysterectomy for a benign condition. Therefore, the best treatment for this woman without contraindications to estrogen use is transdermal estrogen (oral estrogen would also be appropriate). Progesterone is not needed since she has had a hysterectomy.

Management of menopausal symptoms requires an individualized approach that addresses the type and severity of symptoms, the patient’s desire for intervention, and the risks and benefits of treatment. The 2 major types of treatment options for menopausal symptoms include hormonal therapy (menopause hormone therapy; MHT), and non-hormonal therapy. Lifestyle interventions like sleep hygiene, exercise, and stress management should be discussed with all women. Women with a history of breast cancer, coronary heart disease (CHD), a previous venous thromboembolic (VTE) event or stroke, active liver disease, high-risk endometrial cancer, or transient ischemic attack are not candidates for MHT.

The primary goal of MHT is to treat vasomotor symptoms. MHT includes unopposed estrogen in women who have had a hysterectomy and combined estrogen-progestin therapy for women with an intact uterus and the need for progestin to prevent estrogen-associated endometrial hyperplasia. Oral progesterone prevents endometrial growth, which mitigates the risk of hyperplasia and progression to cancer. Patients with a history of a hysterectomy do not need progesterone therapy and transdermal estrogen or oral estrogen are often used to treat vasomotor symptoms in these patients.

Non-hormonal pharmacologic options, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), gabapentin, and clonidine, are alternative treatments that can be effective for managing vasomotor symptoms. They can be used in women who cannot tolerate or have contradictions to or do not want to use hormone therapy. They can also be used in combination with MHT. A progestin-containing IUD can manage abnormal bleeding, but will not address systemic symptoms. Topical vaginal estrogen therapy can be used to treat symptoms of GSM.  

Option Analysis

❌ Oral estrogen and progesterone:
Incorrect: When used in combination with estrogen therapy, progesterone prevents endometrial hyperplasia and future development of cancer in women who have an intact uterus and are being treated with estrogen therapy for menopausal symptoms. Progesterone is not needed for this patient who has had a hysterectomy.  
✅ Transdermal estrogen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lifestyle modifications and re-evaluation in 6 months:
Incorrect: Certain modifications may alleviate mild menopausal symptoms; however, this patient's symptoms, especially her vasomotor symptoms, are debilitating and interfering with her normal functioning. Transdermal estrogen is the best treatment option listed to treat menopausal symptoms in this patient who has had a hysterectomy.  
❌ Transdermal estrogen and oral progesterone:
Incorrect: When used in combination with estrogen therapy, progesterone prevents endometrial hyperplasia and future development of cancer in women who have an intact uterus and are being treated with estrogen therapy for menopausal symptoms. Progesterone is not needed for this patient who has had a hysterectomy.  
❌ Gabapentin:
Incorrect: Gabapentin is effective for treatment of hot flashes in some women and may be considered in women who cannot take or prefer not to take MHT. MHT however, is the most effective treatment for hot flashes and should be used in patients with significant symptoms and disruption of her usual activities.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right sided lower abdominal pain. The patient reports that she has felt pressure in her right lower abdomen over the last month but that the pain became intermittent and severe pain over the last 24 hours.  The patient reports nausea and two episodes of emesis. The patient reports urinary frequency but denies dysuria or hematuria. The patient is not sexually active. Menses began at age 13 yo and her Periods are regular. She has no history of dysmenorrhea or menorrhagia. Last menstrual period was two weeks ago. The patient has no new vaginal discharge or dysuria or frequency. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 111/66 mm Hg, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is alert and appears uncomfortable. Cardiopulmonary examinations are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft with tenderness to palpation in the right pelvic area. Adnexal tenderness on the right. No rebound or guarding are present. Psoas and obturator signs are negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is a 17-year-old girl who presents with mild right sided pelvic pain and adnexal tenderness on the third day of menstruation. She is not sexually active and does not have findings consistent with an acute surgical abdomen or with urinary conditions. She is found to have right adnexal tenderness on exam. The most likely diagnosis is an ovarian cyst. Most ovarian cysts found in аԁοlеѕϲеոts are follicular cysts. Follicular cysts are considered functional or physiologic cysts that occur during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle (during ovulation). The best next step in management is to order a pelvic ultrasound.            

Most causes of acute abdominal pain in pediatric patients are gastrointestinal or genitourinary in origin. Gastrointestinal causes of acute abdominal pain include infectious gastroenteritis, constipation, pancreatitis, cholecystitis, and peptic ulcer disease. Constipation and gastroenteritis are often clinical diagnoses, although stool studies can be used to diagnose specific causes of gastroenteritis. The work-up for pancreatitis and cholecystitis includes obtaining a complete blood count, lipase, amylase, liver function tests (if concern for cholecystitis), and abdominal imaging (CT or ultrasound). Peptic ulcer disease is diagnosed by esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy.        

Urinary causes of acute abdominal pain include urinary tract infections diagnosed with urinalysis and urine culture, and urolithiasis diagnosed via imaging with computed tomography or ultrasound. Anterior cutaneous nerve entrapment is another cause of acute abdominal pain, and the diagnosis can be made clinically. Adolescent patients may present with lower abdominal or pelvic pain related to pelvic organs. Biologically female patients who present with pelvic pain should be evaluated with pelvic ultrasound.    

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Abdominal radiograph :
Incorrect: Abdominal radiographs can be used to evaluate for urolithiasis and constipation. This patient presents with acute right lower abdominal/pelvic pain during the follicular phase of menstruation and is found to have right adnexal tenderness. Pelvic ultrasound should be performed to diagnose a follicular cyst. 
❌ Urine culture:
Incorrect: this patient has no signs or symptoms of urinary infection. She presents with acute right lower abdominal/pelvic pain during the follicular phase of menstruation and is found to have right adnexal tenderness. Pelvic ultrasound should be performed to diagnose a follicular cyst. 
❌ Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT):
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhea and Chlamydia trachomatis nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) should be performed in biologically female patients who are sexually active and present with abdominal/pelvic pain. This patient is not sexually active. She presents with acute right lower abdominal/pelvic pain during the follicular phase of menstruation and is found to have right adnexal tenderness. Pelvic ultrasound should be performed to diagnose a follicular cyst. 
❌ Pap smear:
Incorrect: A Papanicolaou (Pap) smear is a routine test to evaluate for cervical cancer. This patient most likely has a follicular cyst, and pelvic ultrasound should be performed next to make the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of pelvic pain. She has had pain with intercourse and during bowel movements, especially during her menstrual periods, for the last six months and is now having pelvic pain daily. She is sexually active with one biologically male partner, and they have been unsuccessful at conceiving a child despite one year of unprotected intercourse. Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago. Her family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals tenderness during vaginal palpation and immobility of the cervix, without adnexal masses. Serum hCG is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pelvic pain, cyclic dyspareunia and dyschezia (pain with bowel movements), along with pain on vaginal examination and cervical immobility. Given a negative pregnancy test, the next step in management is a pelvic ultrasound to evaluate for radiographic evidence of endometriosis or other pelvic pathology. Infertility can occur as a result of endometriosis and is likely a factor in this patient’s inability to conceive.    

A stable patient presenting with pelvic pain should first be evaluated for pregnancy. After pregnancy has been ruled out, the history and physical will guide the next best step in management.  A patient presenting with a classic history of the 4 “Ds” of endometriosis: dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dyschezia, and dysuria should be evaluated with pelvic ultrasound. Endometriosis is a condition where tissue that normally lines the uterine cavity is found elsewhere in the body. The symptoms may be cyclic or exacerbated by menses. After a thorough examination and a negative pregnancy test, imaging with transvaginal ultrasound should be performed to evaluate for nodular lesions representing ectopic endometrial tissue.  These lesions may occur on the ovary, rectovaginal septum, bladder, or distant locations. Although direct surgical visualization of the ectopic tissue foci is the gold standard for diagnosis, a presumptive diagnosis of endometriosis can be made when the clinical and imaging findings correlate with the condition.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pelvic ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: An MRI may be necessary for surgical planning or in diagnostically complex cases of endometriosis, but a pelvic ultrasound should be the initial diagnostic imaging study.   
❌ Serum CA 125 level:
Incorrect: Although serum CA 125 levels may be elevated in patients with endometriosis, the test is non-specific, and it is not indicated in the workup of suspected endometriosis. Following a pregnancy test, pelvic ultrasound is the next best step. 
❌ Exploratory laparoscopy :
Incorrect: Direct visualization of endometrial tissue outside of the uterine cavity is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis; however, the diagnosis can be presumed based on clinical and imaging findings, avoiding the risks of surgery. 
❌  Initiate letrozole:
Incorrect: Treatment with aromatase inhibitors is typically reserved for patients with severe, refractory pain secondary to endometriosis. A formal diagnosis of endometriosis can be achieved with direct visualization or with imaging and should be established before initiating therapy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the student health clinic for evaluation of one week of mild to moderate pelvic pain. The pain is worse during intercourse and is associated with vaginal spotting after intercourse. The patient has also noted bleeding between periods. She has been sexually active with three biologically male partners over the last month. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. Mild generalized pelvic tenderness is noted on abdominal palpation without rebound or guarding. Chaperoned pelvic examination reveals mucopurulent cervical discharge with cervical motion tenderness on bimanual examination. Urine hCG test is negative. Which of the following is necessary to diagnose the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: No additional tests are required to make the diagnosis

questions.solution:
This patient has multiple sexual partners and is presenting with acute pelvic pain, abnormal vaginal bleeding, mucopurulent cervical discharge, and cervical motion tenderness on examination; she has pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Pelvic inflammatory disease can be diagnosed clinically based on the history, symptoms, and examination findings. Treatment should be initiated based on the clinical impression. Laboratory testing should accompany the clinical diagnosis to identify a causative organism and help guide treatment, but it is not required to make the diagnosis.    

Biologically female patients with acute pelvic pain present a diagnostic challenge given the array of conditions that may cause the pain.  A systematic approach helps to narrow down the most likely etiology, starting with assessing the stability of the patient, followed by pregnancy testing. Pregnant patients with pelvic pain may have an ectopic pregnancy or be experiencing early pregnancy loss. A pelvic ultrasound is the next step in management for these patients. An adnexal mass, with or without adnexal torsion may present with unilateral pelvic pain, abdominal distention, and fullness or tenderness of the adnexa. An ultrasound is also the best initial diagnostic tool for these patients. Endometriosis is best diagnosed with imaging or laparoscopically.    

Occasionally a patient with pelvic pain may not require formal testing for diagnosis, as in the case of primary dysmenorrhea, which can be diagnosed clinically if a patient presents with symptoms of cyclic pelvic pain that began 6-12 months after menarche and abdominal and bimanual examinations are normal. Patients with pelvic inflammatory disease may also be diagnosed without imaging, but laboratory testing should be performed to guide treatment. Intimate partner violence and sexual assault should always be considered in patients presenting with pelvic pain, and the workup for this is dependent on the presenting factors and severity.    

P.S. If you or someone you know are a victim of sexual assault, you can call RAINN National Sexual Assault Telephone Hotline at 800.656.HOPE (4673) or visit rainn.org to be connected with a trained staff member from a sexual assault service provider in your area.  

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. You can also go to thehotline.org/get/help to chat live with an assistance provider. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope For Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources.  

Option Analysis

✅ No additional tests are required to make the diagnosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT):
Incorrect: A contrast-enhanced CT can be helpful when the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is unclear or when there is concern for complications or other conditions such as appendicitis, abscess, or nephrolithiasis. Imaging is not required to make a diagnosis of uncomplicated PID.  
❌ Nucleic acid amplification:
Incorrect: Nucleic acid amplification to identify the causative organism should be performed as part of the management of pelvic inflammatory disease, but it is not required to make the diagnosis or initiate treatment. 
❌ Pelvic ultrasound :
Incorrect: Pelvic ultrasound is indicated for cases of pelvic pain of unknown etiology, especially when an adnexal mass, adnexal torsion, endometriosis, or pregnancy is suspected. Ultrasound can be used to detect complications of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) such as tubo-ovarian abscess. However, imaging is not required to diagnose uncomplicated PID, which in this case is likely based on this patient’s presentation and examination findings. 
❌  Laparoscopy :
Incorrect: Laparoscopy can confirm a diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease but has poor sensitivity, is invasive, and not typically required to manage the condition.

questions.text: A 2-day old neonate is evaluated in the newborn nursery. He was born to a 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, at 34 weeks gestation. After multiple hours of active labor, the fetus developed bradycardia, and the decision was made to proceed with operative vaginal delivery using forceps. The mother has a history of hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the neonate shows asymmetry of the face upon crying, with incomplete closure of the left eye. Upon feeding, he starts drooling from the left side of the mouth. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this neonate’s examination findings?
questions.solution:
This neonate with facial asymmetry and drooling from one side of the mouth has likely suffered trauma to the facial nerve during forceps-assisted delivery, leading to paralysis of the facial muscles.

Congenital traumatic facial nerve paralysis is the loss of controllable (voluntary) muscle movement in an infant's face due to pressure on the facial nerve just before or at the time of birth. Risk factors include primiparity, birth weight > 3.5 kilograms, prolonged labor, and forceps-assisted delivery. Patients usually present with asymmetric facial expressions, difficulty feeding, and incomplete eye closure. Associated findings include ecchymosis, hemotympanum, facial swelling, and head molding. Traumatic congenital facial nerve paralysis usually resolves spontaneously and does not require intervention. If the patient’s eye does not close all the way, an eye pad and eye drops are used to prevent corneal damage.

There is no guaranteed way to prevent pressure injuries during vaginal delivery. The proper use of forceps and improved childbirth methods have reduced the rate of congenital traumatic facial nerve palsy.

Option Analysis

✅ Trauma during forceps delivery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Viral-associated ischemic demyelination:
Incorrect: Viral-associated ischemic demyelination is one of the described etiologies of Bell palsy. Incidence in the neonatal population is negligible. Common pathogens include herpes simplex virus, Epstein Barr virus, etc.
❌ Preterm birth:
Incorrect: Preterm birth has been associated with hypothermia, patent ductus arteriosus, respiratory distress syndrome, glucose abnormalities, necrotizing enterocolitis, and intraventricular hemorrhage. It is not associated with neonatal mononeuropathy.
❌ Maternal hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Untreated maternal hypothyroidism has been associated with preeclampsia, placental abruption, preterm delivery, postpartum hemorrhage, and cognitive impairment in the child. It is not associated with neonatal mononeuropathy.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face due to dual UMN control of the upper face, thereby sparing it. This patient has paralysis of the entire left side of the face, making UMN lesion less likely.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to OB-triage for evaluation of uterine contractions. The patient is 37 weeks gestation and is admitted for labor induction. Once roomed, the anesthesia team begins preparation for administration of analgesia via placement of a catheter in the spine. Following the procedure, the patient has full mobility of the lower extremities and can still feel her contractions. She has no sensation in her pelvic floor and perineum. This procedure involved the administration of an anesthetic agent into which of the following anatomic sites?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for labor induction with a procedure performed that results in anesthesia of the pelvic floor and perineum with retention of musculoskeletal strength and sensation of the lower extremities. These findings are consistent with epidural anesthesia, which reflects the placement of a catheter into the sacral canal.   

The two standard methods of anesthesia during labor include spinal and epidural anesthesia. The anesthetic agent is introduced with a needle into the subarachnoid space at the L3-L4 vertebral level during spinal anesthesia, which produces anesthesia below the waist. This results in loss of pain in the perineum, pelvic floor, and birth canal and the loss of sensation of uterine contractions. In addition, this procedure results in loss of the motor and sensory functions of the bilateral lower extremities. Since this procedure pierces the dura mater and arachnoid mater, it can result in a cerebrospinal fluid leak and postural headache post-procedure.    

In contrast, epidural anesthesia involves anesthesia administered in the sacral canal using an indwelling catheter covering the S2-S4 spinal nerve roots, providing anesthesia to the birth canal, pelvic floor, and perineum while preserving uterine contractions and lower extremity strength and sensation. It also has the advantage of leaving the catheter in the epidural space and administering the anesthesia repeatedly if needed.



Option Analysis

✅ Sacral canal:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subarachnoid space :
Incorrect: The subarachnoid space is the space anesthetized with spinal anesthesia. Unlike epidural anesthesia, spinal anesthesia results in motor and sensory function loss below the waist.   
❌ Subcutaneous tissue :
Incorrect: Local anesthetics are injected into the subcutaneous tissue for regional anesthesia, such as in the setting of laceration repairs, IV placement, or other invasive procedures.  
❌ Pudendal nerve  :
Incorrect: Pudendal nerve blocks are often utilized for diagnosis and management of chronic pelvic pain caused by pudendal neuralgia and for regional anesthesia in other gynecologic, obstetrical, and anorectal procedures.  
❌ Lumbar nerve roots:
Incorrect: Anesthesia of the lumbar nerve roots would result in loss of motor and sensory function in the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for preconception counseling. She wants to become pregnant within the next year and inquires about the steps she should take to ensure a healthy pregnancy. She has no significant medical or surgical history. She is taking a prenatal vitamin. She has not been pregnant previously and has not tried to conceive in the past. She has no history of STIs and is in a monogamous relationship with her partner. She does not drink alcohol or use recreational substances. She has no pets in the house. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following should be performed at this visit?
questions.solution:
Screening for potential risk factors that could affect pregnancy in this patient who has no current medical conditions should include asking about intimate partner violence.

Preconception care focuses on enhancing health, managing changeable risk factors, and offering educational guidance before pregnancy. Its primary aim is to maximize a patient's health for a healthy pregnancy. Asking the patient, "Are you planning to get pregnant in the next year?" can initiate preconception counseling if they respond affirmatively, or lead to a conversation about contraception if they do not. This counseling can occur at a designated appointment or during any interaction with a patient considering pregnancy.

In preconception counseling, comprehensive history and physical examination are essential to address potential risks affecting pregnancy and maternal health. Preconception care includes reviewing the patient’s history for major medical conditions (e.g., thyroid disorders, diabetes mellitus); and screening for substance use, environmental and occupational exposures, risks for infectious diseases, and intimate partner violence.

Physical assessment, tailored to identified risks, typically covers systematic evaluations, focusing on the thyroid, breasts, and pelvic organs. Laboratory testing may include blood tests for rubella and varicella immunity, testing for STIs, and obtaining the status of general health conditions. Genetic carrier screening is considered based on familial or ethnic predispositions. Emphasizing the importance of folic acid supplementation and building a supportive patient-provider relationship is integral to ensuring a healthy pregnancy.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, you can call the U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-SAFE (7233) or text START to 88788 to be connected with a trained staff member for free and confidential support. You can also go to thehotline.org/get/help to chat live with an assistance provider. In Canada, you can visit sheltersafe.ca or call Hope For Wellness 24/7 at 1-855-242-3310 for safety and support services. Additional international support can be found at www.domesticshelters.org/resources.  

Option Analysis

❌ Screening for gestational diabetes:
Incorrect: Screening for gestational diabetes in this patient should be conducted during pregnancy, typically between 24 and 28 weeks gestation. It is not a component of preconception care, which targets current health issues and risks that exist before pregnancy.  
❌ Complete blood count:
Incorrect: A complete blood count (CBC) is not specifically targeted or prioritized in preconception care unless there is a specific clinical indication like a history of chronic diseases.  
❌ Thyroid function tests:
Incorrect: Thyroid function screening is appropriate for patients with pregestational type 1 diabetes, a personal or family history of thyroid disease, age greater than 30, obesity, history of pregnancy loss, preterm delivery, or infertility. This patient does not meet the criteria for preconception screening with thyroid function tests.  
✅ Screening for intimate partner violence:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bone density scan:
Incorrect: Bone density scans are used to diagnose or assess the risk of osteoporosis, a condition not directly related to preconception care or immediate pregnancy planning in patients without a history of osteoporosis or risk factors for osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for an annual well-visit examination. She expresses a desire to become pregnant within the next year and inquires about steps she should take to ensure a healthy pregnancy. She has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with lisinopril. She has never been pregnant or has had prior issues with infertility. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 66/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue lisinopril as it is effectively controlling her blood pressure
Continue lisinopril and add oral folic acid supplementation
Discontinue lisinopril only after a positive pregnancy test
Increase lisinopril dosage to prevent hypertension-related complications in pregnancy

questions.solution:
This patient who is planning on becoming pregnant within the next year should be switched from her current ACE inhibitor to a pregnancy-safe antihypertensive like nifedipine. Agents that block the Renin-angiotensin system, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. These medications have been associated with neonatal kidney failure and death.

Hypertension management should be addressed prior to conception, due to the increased risk of adverse events to both the mother and the fetus from uncontrolled hypertension and from medications used to control blood pressure. Pregnant women with uncontrolled hypertension throughout their pregnancy are at an increased risk of developing preeclampsia and intrauterine growth restriction.

Treatment of hypertension is initiated at a blood pressure threshold of 140/90 mmHg using the fewest medications at the lowest effective dose to maintain blood pressure below this level. Renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), and direct renin inhibitors, are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. Exposure during the second and third trimesters has been associated with neonatal kidney failure and death.

A key component of preconception counseling is to identify use of medications (including over-the-counter and prescription drugs) that are teratogenic, so that they can be changed to safer agents (eg, nifedipine instead of lisinopril). Antihypertensives that are safe to use in the perinatal period include nifedipine, methyldopa, and labetalol.

Patients with long-standing or uncontrolled hypertension who become pregnant should have vision screening, urine protein evaluation, and an electrocardiogram. They should be counseled that they are at an increased risk of developing preeclampsia and intrauterine growth restriction in pregnancy, and they should be started on low-dose aspirin after 12 weeks of gestation to reduce their risk of preeclampsia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Continue lisinopril as it is effectively controlling her blood pressure:
Incorrect: Renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), and direct renin inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. Exposure to these medications during the second and third trimesters has been associated with neonatal kidney failure and death.  
❌ Continue lisinopril and add oral folic acid supplementation:
Incorrect: Folic acid supplementation is important for development of the nervous system in the early fetus. However, renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception.  
❌ Discontinue lisinopril only after a positive pregnancy test:
Incorrect: It is important to switch medications before conception to avoid any exposure to lisinopril during early pregnancy and organogenesis.  
❌ Increase lisinopril dosage to prevent hypertension-related complications in pregnancy:
Incorrect: Renin-angiotensin system blocking agents, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy and should be discontinued before conception. Antihypertensive agents that are safe during pregnancy should be used instead.  
✅ Discontinue lisinopril and start nifedipine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 40 weeks of gestational age is in labor in the hospital and has an epidural in place. Her medical history is notable for an appendectomy at age 12 and a pre-pregnancy body mass index of 34 kg/m2. Her labor progresses spontaneously, and after pushing for 2.5 hours, she delivers a healthy 3600 gm female neonate. Sixty seconds later, the umbilical cord is clamped and cut, and the infant is placed on the maternal abdomen. Maternal vital signs include temperature 36.5°C (97.8°F), pulse 92/min, respirations 18/min, and blood pressure 124/80 mmHg. The patient appears clinically well. Which of the following features would be consistent with a normal third stage of labor?

choices.text: Lowering of the uterus in the abdomen
Sudden shortening of the umbilical cord
45 minutes between delivery of the neonate and placenta

questions.solution:
Normal labor can be divided into 4 stages. The 3rd stage of labor is defined as the period between delivery of the neonate and delivery of the placenta. Following delivery of the neonate, the placenta should spontaneously separate from the uterus, though active management of the third stage of labor is recommended to reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage. Active management of the 3rd stage includes the administration of oxytocin to stimulate uterine contraction, applying gentle downward traction on the umbilical cord, and performing fundal massage. When placental separation occurs, a gush of blood is normally seen, the umbilical cord lengthens, and the uterus may rise slightly in the abdomen. The third stage of labor should last < 30 minutes; if prolonged, manual extraction of the placenta is indicated.       

The 4th stage of labor is defined as the first 2-3 hours postpartum, and 4th stage management can often begin while awaiting delivery of the placenta. This includes repairing lacerations, promoting skin-to-skin and bonding between parent and child, and supporting breastfeeding initiation. The table above reviews the four stages of labor and key management points at each stage.   

Option Analysis

✅ A. Gush of blood :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Soft boggy uterus:
Incorrect: Following delivery, the uterus should clamp down, expelling the placenta and reducing uterine blood loss. A soft, boggy uterus is atonic, which is abnormal and the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.  
❌ Lowering of the uterus in the abdomen:
Incorrect: When placental separation occurs during the 3rd stage of labor the uterus may rise slightly in the abdomen and lowering would not be expected. 
❌ Sudden shortening of the umbilical cord:
Incorrect: When the placenta spontaneously separates from the uterus, a gush of blood and lengthening of the umbilical cord are typically seen. The uterus may also rise in the abdomen. 
❌ 45 minutes between delivery of the neonate and placenta:
Incorrect: The third stage of labor should last < 30 minutes. If the placenta has not been delivered within the first 30 minutes after delivery of the neonate, manual extraction is indicated.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 36 weeks estimated gestational age, presents for a routine prenatal visit. She has had no contractions, loss of fluid, vaginal bleeding, or decreased fetal movement. This pregnancy has been uncomplicated except for group B Streptococcus (GBS) on a routine urine culture obtained at 8 weeks that was treated with antibiotics. Obstetric history is notable for three uncomplicated term vaginal deliveries of healthy neonates, all of which the patient breastfed for at least 6 months postpartum without difficulty. Pre-pregnancy body mass index (BMI) was 24 kg/m2, and she has gained 32 lb. this pregnancy. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. On abdominal exam, the fundus is broad, nodular, and uneven, and a firm, smooth spherical mass is palpable just above the pubic bone. The fundal height measures 38 cm, and the fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following should be performed at this visit?
questions.solution:
Important antenatal counseling includes education on the labor and delivery process, options for intrapartum pain management, breastfeeding education, and discussing plans for postpartum contraception, especially if the patient is or may be interested in permanent sterilization. Counseling should be individualized based on the patient’s history, experience, and expressed desires. For example, in this vignette, the patient has prior experience with labor, delivery, and breastfeeding, and, at 36 with 4 children, she is an excellent candidate for sterilization if that is what she desires. Therefore, discussing postpartum contraception is likely the most important aspect of care at this visit.

During contraceptive counseling, all available options should be reviewed with patients, including non-hormonal options (barriers/condoms, copper intrauterine device [IUD]), progestin-only methods (pills, IUD, subdermal implants, injections), combined estrogen-progestin contraceptives (pills, patch, and vaginal ring), and permanent sterilization (with cesarean, immediately postpartum, interval tubal sterilization, and male vasectomy). IUDs can be placed immediately following placental delivery or at a 6-week postpartum visit. Contraceptive implants and injections can be administered prior to hospital discharge. However, to prevent breastfeeding challenges and venous thromboembolic events, estrogen-containing methods are typically not started until at least 4 weeks postpartum.   

Option Analysis

✅ Counseling on postpartum contraception:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ GBS rectovaginal swab:
Incorrect: This patient had GBS bacteriuria in the first trimester. Therefore, intrapartum prophylactic antibiotics are indicated regardless of any future GBS screening test results, and a new screening test is unnecessary. 
❌ Complete growth ultrasound:
Incorrect: This patient has no risk factors for abnormal fetal growth and fundal height measurement is within 2 cm of EGA. Although the fetal position was determined on abdominal palpation, a limited obstetric ultrasound to confirm the fetal position (rather than a complete growth scan) would be reasonable. 
❌ Breastfeeding education:
Incorrect: Although breastfeeding education is an important topic to cover during antenatal appointments, this patient has a history of successfully breastfeeding 3 prior children. Therefore, breastfeeding education is less important for this patient than reviewing postpartum contraceptive options. 
❌ Pelvic exam :
Incorrect: Without contractions, vaginal bleeding, loss of fluid, abnormal discharge, or other pelvic complaints, a pelvic exam is not indicated during routine antenatal appointments.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, presents in labor at 37 weeks’ gestation. She had a spontaneous vaginal delivery 4 years ago. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 126/86 mmHg. Clinically, she appears well. A fetal heart rate (FHR) tracing shows a baseline rate of 160 bpm with rapid, irregular fluctuations between 155 bpm and 165 bpm. All transient increases in FHR above baseline last less than 15 seconds. The FHR gradually decreases starting at the onset of a contraction, reaching a nadir of 145 bpm simultaneously with the peak of the contraction, and returns to baseline as the contraction ends. Which of the following clinical findings best explains this patient's fetal heart rate tracing?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in labor with fetal heart rate (FHR) findings consistent with early decelerations, which is considered a normal finding that indicates head compression, commonly seen at advanced cervical dilation (in this case, 9 cm). Early decelerations gradually and symmetrically decrease and then return to baseline, mirroring a contraction. They start at the onset of a contraction, reach their nadir at the peak of a contraction, and recover at the end of the contraction. These dips in FHR represent a fetal vagal response to head compression during descent into the pelvis and are commonly seen with advanced cervical dilation.

Intrapartum FHR monitoring serves to detect inadequate fetal oxygenation during labor and allows for intervention before fetal acidemia leads to permanent hypoxic injury. Fetal autonomic responses to mechanical or hypoxic stress reduce the heart rate to reduce myocardial workload.

Clinical factors may predispose patients to certain fetal heart rate patterns. For example, early decelerations are commonly seen with advanced cervical dilation when fetal head compression occurs as the head enters the true pelvis. Variable decelerations, which represent umbilical cord compression, are more common in the setting of ruptured membranes and oligohydramnios. Late decelerations suggest uteroplacental insufficiency and are often observed in conditions associated with microvascular disease, such as hypertensive disorders, pre-gestational diabetes, autoimmune disease, and fetal growth restriction.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Cervical dilation of 9 cm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ruptured membranes and oligohydramnios:
Incorrect: Ruptured membranes and decreased amniotic fluid volume increase the risk of umbilical cord compression, which leads to variable decelerations characterized by abrupt decreases in FHR—findings not seen in this vignette.
❌ Magnesium sulfate:
Incorrect: Magnesium sulfate and opioids are common causes of minimal variability, which is defined as normal fluctuations of the FHR having an overall amplitude of 5 bpm or less. This patient has fluctuations of 10 bpm, indicating moderate variability, which is normal.
❌ Fetal growth restriction (FGR):
Incorrect: FGR is associated with placental insufficiency, which increases the risk of late decelerations. Late decelerations begin, peak, and recover after the onset, peak, and end of a contraction, respectively. In this vignette, the decelerations mirror the contraction, consistent with early decelerations. This is a normal finding that indicates head compression, commonly seen at advanced cervical dilation.
❌ Intrapartum fever:
Incorrect: Intrapartum fever is typically associated with fetal tachycardia, defined as a baseline FHR > 160 bpm. A baseline rate of 160 bpm is normal, even when normal fluctuations (known as variability) rise above 160.
